There is insufficient evidence to support the use of antidepressants as a treatment for symptomatic GAD. There is some evidence that olanzapine has a beneficial effect on GAD symptoms, but the evidence is not strong enough to support its use. More high quality, well-designed and reported randomised controlled trials are needed to confirm or refute the effectiveness of this intervention in the treatment of GAD.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of moderate intensity aerobic exercise for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the effect of exercise on morbidity and mortality in people with type 1 diabetes.

There is insufficient evidence to determine whether ischemic preconditioning reduces the risk of myocardial infarction, major adverse cardiac events or mortality in patients undergoing elective endovascular aneurysm repair. There is a need for more randomised clinical trials with larger sample sizes to determine the effect of ischemic preconditioning on patient-important outcomes.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of group voice therapy for people with mild to moderate cognitive impairment. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials to assess the effectiveness of this intervention.

The use of long-acting beta2 agonists and inhaled corticosteroids should not be used for the treatment of moderate to very severe COPD. There is no evidence to support the routine use of this combination in the management of exacerbations requiring COPD.

Exercise is an effective treatment for reducing depressive symptoms in people with major depression. However, there is little experimental evidence to support the use of exercise as a sole treatment for depression. More research is needed to clarify the relative benefits of different types of exercise in conjunction with or without pharmacological intervention.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of aminophylline as a treatment for acute asthma in children. There is no clear evidence that aminophylline is superior to intravenous aminophylline in the initial treatment of severe acute asthma, and further studies are required to determine the relative benefits and harms of aminophylline compared with salbutamol.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of caring for long-stay care for adults, children or adults with psychotic impairments. There is a need for well designed, conducted and reported randomised clinical trials with adequate power to evaluate the impact of caring on long-term outcomes.

The available data do not support the routine use of alpha-blockers to reduce the risk of major vascular events in patients with hypercholesterolaemia. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised clinical trials with adequate power to assess the benefits and harms of different therapeutic options for hypercholesterolaemia.

This review provides some evidence that beta-blockers are more effective than propranolol for the prophylaxis of migraine without aura, and that propranolol 160 mg daily is less effective than 5 mg daily in terms of reducing duration of headache days and headache severity. There was no evidence of benefit for any other adverse event profile. There is insufficient evidence to determine which treatment is the most appropriate for patients with migraine.

This review provides some evidence that IPT, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, was superior to placebo for treating depression and thoracic symptoms in the first half of post-myocardial infarction depression. However, there was no evidence of a difference in the rate of serious adverse cardiac events between the two types of trials. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed RCTs with adequate power to evaluate the effect of antidepressant medication compared to other medical treatments.

There is some evidence to support the use of topical honey as a treatment for radiation-induced oral mucositis in patients with head and neck cancer. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of metronidazole gel for treating fungating tumours. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCTs of 6% Miltefosine as a palliative treatment for breast cancer. A large scale RCT conducted over a greater period of time is needed to assess the efficacy of this treatment.

Interferon-beta-2A appears to reduce the number of influenza site episodes associated with remission in patients with active ulcerative colitis. However, this conclusion is limited because of the small number of trials included in this review and small numbers of patients and the small sample sizes in each comparison, the results should be treated with caution. Further well-designed, high quality randomised controlled trials are required to determine whether interferon alpha are safe or effective in the treatment of patients with ulcerative colitis due to the lack of a significant side effect profile.

There is some evidence that propofol is an effective researchers sedation with a low dose of midazolam and a similar recovery time than propofol in reducing pain and pain-related outcomes in patients undergoing colonoscopy. However, propofol is associated with a higher rate of recovery time and a lower rate of arterial blood pressure compared with the same dose. The use of propofol was associated with higher rates of withdrawal due to adverse events than propofol alone. There was no evidence of a difference in recovery time between propofol and midazolam and intravenous midazolam in terms of patient satisfaction, recovery times and time to recovery. Patients receiving propofol showed better recovery time compared to patients receiving propofol alone but there was no difference in patient satisfaction between the two groups. Further well-designed RCTs are required to determine which sedation is the most appropriate

Vitamin C had no significant effect on the duration and severity of the common cold, the duration of cold symptoms and the duration or severity of cold episodes in healthy children. However, vitamin C supplementation was associated with a significant reduction in the incidence of upper respiratory tract infection, but there was no evidence of an effect on colds.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine whether the choice of electrical stimulation is more effective than either no or no treatment or other electrical stimulation for preventing motor impairments in the hand of arthritic hands. There is a need for more high quality, well designed randomised controlled studies with larger sample sizes to investigate the effects of different electrical stimulation methods for motor impairments.

Tretinoin administered topically in 0.1% concentration has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe photoaged skin. There is insufficient evidence to determine whether the application of a 5% laser is more effective than a CO2 laser for the treatment of otorrhoea. In the majority, there is some evidence to suggest that any one type of laser is better than another. There was no evidence to support the use of any one class of laser alone for treating otorrhoea.

The available evidence suggests that the combination of transdermal nitroglycerin and corticosteroid infiltration may be superior to placebo in treating shoulder pain. Topical glyceryl trinitrate may reduce pain intensity at night and at rest when compared with placebo in patients with rotator cuff tendinitis but no conclusions can be made regarding the long-term benefit or adverse effects.

There is some evidence that olanzapine was superior to placebo for reduction of relapse even in schizophrenia, but it was associated with a significant reduction in prolactin elevation. There was no statistically significant difference in efficacy between haloperidol and other commonly-used atypical drugs. Side effects for all medications were minimal and included slight to moderate EPS and drowsiness. There were no major adverse reactions associated with the use of olanzapine.

The use of Shouldice inguinal hernia repair seems to be superior to the use of open mesh repair in terms of the recurrence of the inguinal hernia. There is insufficient evidence to determine which method of repair is the most appropriate for inguinal hernia repairs, and there is some evidence that the Shouldice technique is associated with fewer recurrence rates than the technique with absorbable suture. There was no evidence of a difference in recurrence rates between the two techniques. There are no randomised controlled trials comparing the Shouldice and open mesh methods for the management of decreasing the risk of recurrence of patients with a primary inguinal hernia, and further trials are needed to confirm this.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of oral vancomycin for the prevention of NEC in preterm, very low birthweight neonates. There is a need for more high quality, well designed randomised controlled trials with adequate numbers of babies to evaluate the effects of this intervention.

Dimenhydrinate reduces the number of episodes of vomiting from acute gastroenteritis and the proportion of children with mild to moderate dehydration who failed attempts at oral rehydration. However, it is associated with a higher rate of diarrheal episodes and a lower risk of vomiting when compared to placebo. Further well-designed RCTs are required to determine the optimal dose and duration of ondansetron for the treatment of acute gastroenteritis in children.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of splints in the treatment of patients with de Quervain's disease of pregnancy and fetal. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised controlled trials with adequate numbers of patients to determine the efficacy, tolerability and safety of different splints techniques for these patients.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the effectiveness of educational interventions for preventing the incidence of AD. There is a need for more high quality, well designed, conducted and reported randomised controlled trials in this field.

This updated meta-analysis confirms that nifedipine-containing therapy is effective in reducing cardiotoxicity of anthracycline-induced cardiac disease in women with early-stage breast cancer and soft tissue sarcomas. However, there is no evidence of a difference in overall survival, time to progression, and event-free survival between nifedipine- and doxorubicin-containing drugs. The available data do not support the routine use of EPI as a first-line treatment for anthracycline-associated cardiotoxicity.
In women who are early stage II or III, EPI significantly reduced the risk of ototoxicity when compared to no treatment. There is a need for more randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to evaluate the safety of EPI.

This review provides some evidence that once-daily tramadol is an effective analgesic for the treatment of OA pain. There is no evidence that the combination of tramadol and celecoxib was more effective than placebo for pain relief, but this was not associated with increased adverse events. More high quality, well-designed and reported trials are needed to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this intervention.

Venom immunotherapy significantly reduces the size and duration of the large local reactions but did not reduce the risk of systemic reactions without increasing systemic adverse events. There was no evidence of benefit for SLIT in reducing the size or duration of treatment allocations. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow-up to assess the effect of SLIT on systemic reactors.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of multisystemic therapy for improving the treatment of child physical abuse and neglect. There is a need for further high quality research in this field.

Natalizumab appears effective in reducing remission and response in patients with active Crohn's disease. There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of alpha4 integrin as induction and maintenance therapy for patients with moderate-to-severe active disease.

For patients with refractory septic shock, low-dose vasopressin significantly reduced the risk of all-cause mortality when compared with placebo, but there was no evidence of benefit in terms of mortality at discharge from intensive care, length of hospital stay, or a reduction in arterial blood pressure more than 70 mm Hg.

Limited evidence suggests that 5-ASA is superior to placebo in the treatment of reducing remission in patients with active Crohn's disease. There was no evidence of a difference in efficacy between the two drugs, but there was no statistically significant difference in safety between these drugs and placebo. There is a need for further large, high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow-up to determine the optimal dose and frequency of treatment to be better than placebo for the induction of adverse events associated with this drug. The data from this review do not provide sufficient evidence to support or refute the routine use of this intervention in clinical practice as a first line treatment for patients with moderate and severe adverse events.

reductase fixation is effective in the treatment of displaced fractures of the distal end of the radius. However, there is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of external fixation as a treatment for the most severely intra-articular fractures. Further well-designed randomised controlled trials are needed to determine which types of fixation or plaster are the most effective methods for treating these fractures.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support the use of medication combined with parent training or self-control for the treatment of ADHD symptoms. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed and reported long-term RCTs that compare the effectiveness and safety of these two commonly used approaches, including pharmacotherapy, in treating children with ADHD.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of combination chemotherapy with or without interferon alpha for the treatment of patients with metastatic melanoma. However, there is some evidence that chemotherapy with interferon alpha is associated with a modest improvement in overall survival and progression-free survival compared with the use of chemotherapy alone. The addition of IFN-alpha to the combination of interferon-alpha and cisplatin does not appear to be associated with an improvement in progression free survival and overall survival when compared with either alone.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of calcitonin to prevent corticosteroid-induced osteopenia bone loss in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. There is uncertainty about the best treatment for steroid-dependent asthmatics associated with osteoporosis.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support the use of inhaled beta2-agonists in the treatment of severe acute asthma. There is some evidence that nebulised salbutamol given intravenously was more effective than nebulised salbutamol at a dose of 2.0 mg/kg/day for the initial treatment of acute asthma, but the clinical significance of this is still unclear. However, nebulised salbutamol was associated with a higher rate of adverse events and a lower length of hospitalisation than inhaled salbutamol.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of postal reminders in primary care for patients who have survived an acute coronary event and to support follow up care for those who are able to be at increased risk of cardiovascular disease, but no evidence of effect on all-cause and cardiovascular mortality. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials that examine the effectiveness of different types of reminders for primary care patients with acute coronary events.

Synacdesigned Depot is effective in reducing the severity of post-puncture headache after spinal anesthesia, however there is no evidence to support its use in the treatment of patients undergoing this procedure.

In patients with Parkinson's disease and wearing-off motor fluctuations, pramipexole 200 mg was significantly more effective than bromocriptine 200 mg in increasing reductions in daily off-time and improves motor function in patients with motor fluctuations. There was no evidence of a difference in efficacy between tolcapone 200 mg and bromocriptine 100 mg. However, tolcapone was associated with a higher rate of adverse events, including nausea, cramps, and dystonia. There were no major differences in safety data.

There is insufficient evidence from this review to support the routine use of laparoscopically assisted versus open RIectomy for Crohn's disease. There is a need for more randomised clinical trials with adequate numbers of patients and well designed clinical trials to determine the relative benefits and harms of these two or more methods for the primary and secondary surgical management of this condition. Further well designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up are needed.

Lifestyle-plus-exercise interventions led to a significant reduction in the incidence of diabetes in high-risk individuals, but there was no evidence of effect on the rate of diabetes. Lifestyle intervention reduced the incidence and prevalence of diabetes by approximately 30% and type 2 diabetes when compared with no treatment, respectively, and by approximately 28% of participants in the control group. There was insufficient evidence to determine the effect of different types of lifestyle intervention on the incidence or prevalence of developing diabetes.

This review provides some evidence that self-care education has a positive effect on the number of days lost through day of emergency department services and improved the quality of life compared with no intervention. However, this conclusion is limited by the small number of included trials and the lack of reporting of adverse effects in the included trials. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with adequate power to evaluate the effect of education on exacerbations and health outcomes for patients with asthma.

In patients with moderate to very severe COPD, the combination of fluticasone propionate and salmeterol significantly reduced FEV1 and the risk of exacerbations requiring oral corticosteroids compared with regular formoterol and placebo. The risk of pneumonia was not different for active (3.4% vs.0.9%) and for higher rates of pneumonia at the endpoint. Budesonide/formoterol combined in one hydrofluoroalkane pressurized metered inhaler is more effective than formoterol and in combination with a single inhaler and is associated with a higher rate of pneumonia.

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMZ) is an effective prophylactic treatment for the treatment of HIV-infected patients with good hypersensitivity to TMP-SMX. However, its effectiveness remains uncertain due to the small number of available RCTs and the small sample sizes of the available trials. There is insufficient evidence to determine whether or not TMP-SMZ has any effect on the incidence of adverse reactions related to PCP prophylaxis. Further well-designed, adequately powered RCTs are required to assess the effectiveness of these drugs in this patient population.

There is insufficient evidence to support routine use of antibiotics prior to ERCP for the prevention of cholangitis after retrograde cholangiopancreatography. There is some evidence that antibiotics reduced the incidence of post-surgical pancreatitis following ERCP in patients with a biliary tract stones and bile duct stricture, however this was not associated with a reduction in the rate of pneumothorax.

There is some evidence that milnacipran 100 mg/day is an effective treatment for reducing pain and associated symptoms in people with fibromyalgia. There is no evidence to suggest that milnacipran is associated with a significant beneficial effect on mood or sleep in the short-term treatment of people with FM. There are no clinically meaningful improvements in mood, sleep or pain in the long-term, but this was not statistically significant due to the small number of trials included in this review. More high quality, well-designed RCTs are needed to assess the effects of milnacipran on pain, fatigue, mood and other symptoms associated with FM, and to determine whether milnacipran is more effective than placebo in the treatment of pain, other symptoms, or other factors that are associated with adverse effects.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support the routine use of a foods diet for the management of eczema in children and young people. There is some evidence that a high level of antigen avoidance may be beneficial in the short-term management of atopic eczema, but this finding was not statistically significant due to the small number of included trials and the small sample sizes of the included trials. However, there was insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of an formula to reduce the risk of eczema or their skin condition. Further well-designed, adequately powered and well-executed trials are needed to assess the benefits and harms associated with various types of foods and to determine the optimal type and duration of foods.

There is some evidence that prosthetic foot designs such as the SACH and S GHS are effective in achieving foot contact with the floor. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine if the long-term impact of different designs on the clinical outcome of amputation is established. There is a need for further well designed, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials that assess the effect of prosthetic designs on quality of life, service use and gait in people with traumatic and knee disarticulation amputation.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of misoprostol as induction of uterine rupture induction in women with previous cesarean delivery. There is a need for more randomized clinical trials with adequate numbers of women to determine whether or not oxytocin is used for induction of fetal rupture in the short term.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support the routine use of prostaglandin E1 in the treatment of idiopathic sudden sensorineural hearing loss. However, there is a need for high quality, adequately powered, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCTs to confirm or refute the benefits and harms of this intervention.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the effectiveness of airway clearance techniques in the treatment of bronchiectasis. There is a need for further well designed, conducted and reported randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine its efficacy.

Topical medicinal herbs are effective in reducing symptoms and improving the quality of life of HIV-1 disease in adults and persons with human immunodeficiency virus disease. There is no evidence to support the routine use of medicinal herbs in the treatment of symptoms associated with HIV disease. For HIV disease progression, medicinal herbs had no statistically significant effect on CD4 counts < 250 and 500 x 10(9)/L but not on the disease burden of at least two to three times higher than that of placebo. For the management of HIV disease, Chinese medicinal herbs appear to be safe and may be more effective than no treatment.

Epidural anaesthesia and epidural analgesia significantly reduced the risk of postoperative mortality, myocardial infarction, stroke, and major complications in patients undergoing major abdominal surgery. However, there was no evidence that perioperative epidural anaesthesia may be associated with a higher incidence of postoperative respiratory failure, which is associated with an increase in the length of hospital stay and reduced length of stay in intensive care.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine whether intravesical therapy is more effective than immunotherapy immunotherapy in the treatment of patients with infrequent bladder cancer. However, this conclusion should be viewed with caution due to the small number of patients included in the trials.

Nicergoline is effective in reducing the number of adverse events associated with cognitive impairment in patients with mild to moderate dementia, however, there is insufficient evidence to support or refute its use.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine whether groin dissection is superior to radiation in the treatment of adult patients with refractory groin nodes in terms of relief from groin relapses. Large, well-designed, multicentre, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCTs are needed to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from groin dissection.

Manual removal of the placenta at cesarean delivery appears to be associated with a greater risk of endometritis than spontaneous delivery. However, there was no evidence of a difference in post-cesarean endometritis between the two types of removal. There was no statistically significant difference in operative blood loss with the use of manual removal compared with spontaneous delivery; no difference was found in the incidence of postpartum endometritis. The effect of placental removal on blood loss during cesarean delivery needs to be evaluated in randomised controlled trials.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of culturally sensitive videotape as a supplement to standard maternal behaviour change for adolescent mothers and their infants. There is a need for well designed, conducted and reported long-term randomised controlled trials with adequate power to evaluate the effects of this intervention.

This review confirms that PTFE is superior to the current first choice of bypass graft material in terms of short-term patency compared to the first choice for above-knee arterial bypass grafting. However, we found no statistically significant difference in secondary patency between PTFE and a range of medium- and long-term concern types. There was no evidence of a difference in the risk of major amputation, rest pain, pain-related ulceration or ipsilateral amputation when compared to one type 2 on bypass graft. The use of PTFE grafts was associated with a lower risk of peri-implantation amputation compared to a higher risk of postoperative complications, but there was no difference in all-cause mortality.

This review provides some evidence that mirror therapy reduces pain and improves function in patients with CRPSt1 of the affected upper limb after stroke. However, the available data do not support the routine use of mirror therapy to prevent such recovery in the post-stroke period. There is a need for more randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to evaluate the effects of this intervention.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine which method of composite restoration is the most appropriate for the treatment of post-ceramic crowns treated premolars with fiber highly and the clinical success rate of the different types of the procedure. Large, well-designed and reported randomised clinical trials are needed.

There is insufficient evidence to support routine administration of phenobarbital to reduce the incidence of intraventricular haemorrhage in preterm infants weighing 1500 g or less at birth. There is no clear evidence that routine phenobarbital has a beneficial effect on the incidence or severity of preterm birth.

The available literature does not support the use of sulpiride as an effective treatment for schizophrenia, but there is insufficient evidence to support its use in clinical practice. There is a need for well designed, conducted and reported long-term randomised clinical trials that evaluate the efficacy and safety of sulpiride in this patient population.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of rTMS in the treatment of acute ischaemic stroke. There is some evidence that a single session of rTMS over the left hemisphere is associated with a significant improvement in the motor learning of the affected hand in patients after stroke; thus, it is not clear whether it has an effect on functional impairment.

Nasogastric decompression significantly reduced the incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting in patients undergoing abdominal surgery for trauma or NEC. However, the clinical significance of the correct tube used is still unclear. There is a need for more randomised clinical trials with long-term follow-up to determine the safety and effectiveness of correct tube decompression in the management of trauma and NEC.

There is no evidence of a significant difference in overall survival with chemotherapy in the treatment of women with recurrent or refractory cervical cancer. Non-oral chemotherapeutic drugs are associated with a higher response rate, a lower risk of death and a higher risk of progression-free survival when compared with chemotherapy alone. There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of chemotherapy for women with advanced or recurrent cervical cancer to reduce the risk of neutropenia, nausea and vomiting, rash, and thrombocytopenia.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of Vitamin A supplementation to infants and their babies to reduce the risk of developing maternal vitamin A deficiency. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of corticosteroids in the treatment of acute vestibular neuritis. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to assess the effect of corticosteroids on patients' recovery.

This review found no evidence to support the routine use of influenza vaccine as a treatment for ALL. However, there is insufficient evidence to conclude that the influenza vaccine is effective in reducing the risk of influenza infection in children with cancer.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of psychotherapy for women with depression in the short term. There is a need for well designed, conducted and reported randomised controlled trials that compare psychotherapy with standard care for this group of women. The findings of this review should be interpreted with caution due to the small number of women included in the studies and the lack of reporting of adverse effects in many of the included studies.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of low-dose heparin prophylaxis to reduce the incidence of deep venous thromboembolism in patients with hip fracture. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials investigating the efficacy of this intervention.

There is no evidence to support the routine use of any one solution for fluid resuscitation in the treatment of patients with severe injuries. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to assess mortality and morbidity outcomes. Such trials should be reported according to the CONSORT guidelines (www.consort-statement.org/).

There is no evidence that antifungal therapy reduces the risk of IA in adults and children with a high risk of invasive aspergillosis. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to assess the relative sensitivity and specificity of antifungal therapy.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of intermittent left nerve stimulation as an effective treatment for partial-onset seizure types. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed and reported randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this treatment.

There is some evidence that psychological therapy for children and adolescents with PTSD leads to a significant reduction in PTSD diagnostic remission and depressive symptoms compared with no treatment. There is insufficient evidence to determine whether the differential responses are more effective than the waiting list or no treatment when compared with other forms of psychological therapy. The studies included in this review were of short duration and used a number of outcomes that were measured at six months and at one month follow up. The findings of this review support the use of a wide range of psychological approaches for the treatment of children with PTSD in the context of well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow-up.

There is no evidence to support the use of hepatic arterial chemoembolization in the treatment of unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma. There is some evidence that these modalities are associated with a higher tumor response and a lower survival rate than either symptomatic or non-surgical treatment, but it does not improve both the overall survival and the quality of life of patients.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support the use of tocolysis for preventing preterm birth in women with preterm uterine contractions to reduce the risk of pregnancy outcomes. Further well-designed, randomised clinical trials are required to determine whether intravenous tocolysis is superior to observation alone for preventing recurrent preterm uterine activity and to assess the effectiveness of tocolysis as an adjunctive therapy for preventing pregnancy outcomes in this group of women.

This review provides some evidence to support the use of calcium antagonists to prevent graft loss after kidney transplantation. However, there is no evidence that calcium antagonists are associated with a significant reduction in the risk of rejection or graft loss. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed and reported randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to assess the effects of these drugs.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of oral cephalosporins for the treatment of severe pyelonephritis in children. There is some evidence that oral cephalosporins may be superior to parenteral treatment in reducing the number of resolution of vomiting, vomiting-related adverse events and the resolution of hydration state in children with severe pyelonephritis. No significant adverse effects were observed in children treated orally and 5% in non-users. There was no significant difference in the incidence of symptomatic reinfections between the oral and parenteral cephalosporins. There were no significant differences in clinical outcomes between the two groups in terms of time to defervescence, clinical signs and symptoms.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of amantadine as adjuvant to levodopa for motor complications in patients with early-stage PD. Large, multicentre, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCTs are needed to assess the effect of amantadine on motor complications and to determine the safety of this treatment.

There is no evidence to support the routine use of oral corticosteroids in the treatment of multiple sclerosis. There is a lack of evidence that high dose oral corticosteroids are effective in treating patients with exacerbations that are at risk for attacks of MS, but the evidence is not strong enough to suggest a beneficial effect of this treatment.

In patients with moderate to severe heartburn, esomeprazole 40 mg once daily appears to be more effective than cisapride 20 mg twice daily for short-term relief of gastrointestinal symptoms of heartburn. However, it is associated with a higher incidence of adverse events. There was no evidence of a difference in efficacy between the two commonly used treatments. There is a need for further high-quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow-up to determine the optimal timing and duration of treatment for these patients.

There is insufficient evidence to determine whether antibiotics should be used to prevent umbilical catheterization in newborn infants. Future research should focus on the use of antibiotics to reduce umbilical morbidity and mortality in preterm infants, as well as the safety of such antibiotics.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of cimetidine, tramadol, and ceftriaxone for the induction of anaesthesia to reduce the risk of aspiration pneumonitis in elective caesarean section. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow-up to determine the optimal dose and duration of treatment.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of a low glycaemic index diet for women with GDM to reduce the need for insulin therapy and improve pregnancy outcomes. There is some evidence that the choice of low glycaemic control is associated with a higher incidence of adverse pregnancy outcomes than the use of conventional high glycaemic control.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of CBT for treating drug users with and without BPD. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials that explicitly address the effects of such services.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of a glass ionomer cement as a orthodontic adhesive compared with an acrylic resin in the treatment of stainless steel orthodontic brackets. However, the quality of the evidence is not strong enough to rule out clinically important differences in bracket survival between the two types of bonding materials.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine whether risperidone is more effective than clozapine or other treatment modalities for people with schizophrenia. There is a need for well designed, adequately powered, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCTs to assess the effect of risperidone on patient-important outcomes.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of antenatal preparation classes for the prevention of mother and infant birth after a first-line prenatal care or repeat prenatal care. There is some evidence that antenatal preparation is associated with a reduction in the probability of vaginal birth following a history of repeat repeat cesarean and after an 8-month period of prenatal care, but there is no evidence that it may be associated with an increase in knowledge of the mother or infant. Further research is needed to assess the role of antenatal education and support as a means for the management of women with previous cesarean delivery.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of long-acting anesthetic agents in the treatment of acute spinal cord injury. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised clinical trials that evaluate the effect of different therapeutic options on complications and functional outcome in patients treated within 24 hours after injury.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support or refute the use of iridoplasty in the treatment of adult patients with primary angle-closure or primary angle closure conditions. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up.

Compared with HCV genotype 3, 3, 4 and 5, interferon alpha2b is more effective than interferon plus ribavirin for HCV genotype 1 or 4 but not for hepatitis C virus (HIV) infection in HIV-infected patients. However, there is no evidence of a difference in efficacy between interferon and ribavirin, and no statistically significant differences in efficacy or safety between these two drugs.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of acyclovir for the treatment of acute herpes zoster. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the effect of acyclovir on chronic pain and post-herpetic neuralgia.

In patients with McArdle disease, there is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of short-acting and long-acting protein in the treatment of symptomatic exercise. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials that examine the efficacy of different types of protein in reducing exercise capacity and improving phosphorus 31 nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy in patients with myophosphorylase deficiency.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of fluoxetine for treating SAD. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this treatment.

Topotecan and paclitaxel are effective in reducing the risk of progression-free survival and/or overall survival in patients with advanced epithelial ovarian cancer who are in complete response following first-line chemotherapy. In addition, it is associated with a higher risk of grade 3 or 4 tumour recurrence. There was no evidence of a difference in overall survival between the six courses of platinum+FU compared with observation, but the difference was not statistically significant.

Cervical cerclage appears to be an acceptable alternative to expectant management for the treatment of placentaTooth. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine whether cervical cerclage has any effect on the maternal or neonatal outcomes for women with persistent placentaantia.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of MMC to prevent the rate of postoperative visual loss in eyes undergoing Ahmed Glaucoma Valve implantation for neovascular glaucoma. However, there is no evidence of a difference in the risk of surgical complications between the MMC and the Schocket procedure. There is a need for more high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the optimal dose and duration of MMC for the management of patients with refractory glaucoma.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine whether the position of fibroids removal prior to IUI reduces the risk of reproductive outcomes in pregnancy rates after myomectomy. Further well-designed, adequately powered randomised clinical trials with long-term surveillance studies are required.

There is a lack of evidence to support the routine use of Multiphasic-encapsulated doxorubicin as first-line chemotherapy for women with metastatic breast cancer. However, it is not clear which patients might benefit from this treatment.

There is some evidence that physical therapy aimed at reducing self-reported symptoms and balance in patients with persistent and chronic BPPV is associated with a significant reduction in the likelihood of postural control, dizziness-related symptoms and a significant decrease in the perceived score of balance. However, it does not seem to offer any advantage over standard care for patients with moderate to severe vertigo.
There is insufficient evidence to determine which type of therapeutic intervention is the most effective, compared to standard care or usual medical care, for reducing symptoms or balance in BPPV. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to evaluate the effects of rehabilitation on these outcomes.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of lumbar spine radiography as a diagnostic test for the diagnosis of vertebral fracture, possible infection, or the prevalence of serious pathology in patients presenting to primary care for acute LBP.

This review provides some evidence that the beta 1-receptor-selective blockade is an effective treatment for at least 50% increases in lung function in patients with moderate to severe airway obstruction compared with placebo. There is a need for further well designed, conducted and reported long-term randomised controlled trials to determine the effect of this drug on airway obstruction.
There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of any of the commonly used prophylactic interventions for the treatment of DVT after acute ischemic stroke.

There is insufficient evidence to support the effectiveness of relaxation training for reducing the levels of stress in certain types of health professionals. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed RCTs that test relaxation training as a means of reducing self-reported stress levels in health professionals, and that larger studies that compare relaxation training with other types of care are needed. More research is needed to identify the best relaxation training approach for health professionals and to identify which types of relaxation are the most effective, safe and effective strategy for improving self-perceived health status for nurses and health professionals' satisfaction.

There is no evidence to support the routine use of alpha-blockers to reduce the risk of recurrence of syncope in patients with a positive head-up tilt test. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of alpha-tocopherol as a treatment for the treatment of HD. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised controlled trials with adequate numbers of participants, placebo-controlled studies, and long-term follow-up periods that assess the effect of alpha on functional capacity and general motor function in patients with HD.

There is insufficient evidence to support progesterone as luteal support in women undergoing ART cycles to reduce the risk of OHSS and clinical pregnancy rates. However, there is no evidence of a difference in live birth rates between these two progesterone protocols.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of abdominal decompression as a treatment for pre-eclampsia. A randomised controlled trial of longer duration of follow-up may be justified.
[Note: The six citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

Acupuncture administered after spontaneous rupture of membranes at term significantly reduces the time elapsed from the time to delivery and the length of induction of labour in nulliparous women with a singleton assisted Bishop scores of less than 7. Acupuncture may be beneficial for women with active labour, but the clinical significance of this is unclear. There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of acupuncture as a pharmacological agent to reduce the initiation of labour. Acupuncture should not be used outside randomised clinical trials.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine whether Ginkgo biloba is beneficial or harmful for treatment of patients with tinnitus. There is a need for high quality, well designed RCTs that compare Ginkgo biloba with other forms of treatment for patients with dementia and that it is not possible to determine which patients benefit from this treatment.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the routine use of calcitonin in the treatment of giant cellTooth. However, there is a need for high quality, well-designed, adequately powered randomised controlled clinical trials with long-term follow up to assess the effects of calcitonin treatment on tumour volume and tumour response in patients with giant cellantia.

There is no evidence to support the use of cyproterone acetate in the treatment of acne vulgaris. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term surveillance that compare the effectiveness and safety of this combined oral contraceptive with those of other oral contraceptives.

Aliskiren is an effective dose-response drug for the treatment of blood pressure lowering reductions in patients with hypertension. The BP lowering effect of once-daily oral renin inhibitors has not been shown to be similar to that of placebo in the long-term, although there was no statistically significant difference between groups in the incidence of adverse events.

Off-pump bypass surgery is associated with a higher incidence of graft occlusion and a lower incidence of major adverse cardiac and cerebrovascular events; however, the quality of the evidence was very low for all-cause mortality and a higher risk of major morbidity. There was no evidence of a difference in the length of hospital stay between off-pump and on-pump operations. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the optimal type and duration of surgery.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of follow-up after primary surgery for colorectal cancer. Large multi-centre randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up are needed to determine the relative benefits and harms of this intervention.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of cognitive rehabilitation for people with Alzheimer's disease. There is some evidence that cognitive rehabilitation has a positive effect on cognition, memory, mood and mood-related quality of life, but it is unclear what is the most effective treatment for these people. More high quality, well-designed and reported RCTs are needed to confirm or refute the effectiveness of these interventions.

This review provides some evidence that multidisciplinary nursing programmes to increase patients' pain control for post-surgical women with cancer can be effective. However, it is not clear which type of nursing programmes is most effective. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the effectiveness of these interventions. More research is needed to identify the best way to improve the evidence base for the management of cancer pain.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of systemic or low-dose thrombolysis for the treatment of acute VTE. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this treatment.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of propofol for the treatment of RSE. A large scale RCT conducted over a greater period of time is needed to determine whether propofol is superior to placebo in terms of reducing the frequency and severity of status epilepticus. Further well-designed, adequately powered RCTs are needed to assess the effectiveness and safety of propofol as a treatment for RSE in adults. Such trials should be reported according to the CONSORT guidelines (www.consort-statement.org/).
[Note: The four citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

The results of this review support routine use of antibiotics in the treatment of women in preterm labour with intact membranes to reduce the risk of neonatal mortality and neonatal infectious morbidity. Antibiotic treatment had no significant effect on the rate of neonatal sepsis, preterm birth or preterm birth weight when compared with placebo.

This review provides some evidence to support the routine use of tacrolimus for treating remission in children with steroid-resistant FSGS. There is insufficient evidence to determine which patients benefit from this treatment and which type of therapy with tacrolimus is most effective and safe than with oral or intravenous steroids. The available data do not allow us to draw firm conclusions about the effect of tacrolimus on patient-important outcomes. Further well-designed, adequately powered randomised controlled trials are required to determine whether there are any differences in efficacy or safety between tacrolimus and other anti-inflammatory drugs, or other steroids, for patients with steroid resistant or mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis.

Until limited data do not support the routine use of nifedipine for treating women with threatened preterm labour. There is insufficient evidence to determine whether nifedipine is more effective than betasympathicomimetic drugs as a tocolytic treatment for preventing preterm labour, and there is some evidence that it is associated with fewer maternal side-effects.
[Note: The 23 citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of this review once assessed.]

There is currently no evidence to support the use of oral tartrazine oral challenge to reduce the risk of lung function in patients with chronic asthma. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine which method of action is most effective and efficient for the management of these patients. Further well-designed, high quality randomised controlled trials are needed to assess the effect of this intervention on lung function and quality of life in asthmatic patients.
[Note: The six citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the new review once assessed.]

There is insufficient evidence to determine which methods of surgical intervention are the most appropriate for the treatment of TMJ osteoarthrosis and internal derangement. Further well-designed, adequately powered randomised controlled trials are required to confirm or refute these findings.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of indomethacin as a treatment for people with Alzheimer's disease. Further well-designed, large scale, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCTs are needed to assess the effect of indomethacin on long-term cognitive function.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support the use of silver foam dressings to promote the healing of venous leg ulcers in the short term. There is a need for well-designed, adequately powered, multicentre, multicentre randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine whether the degree is more effective than other types of wound healing dressing.
[Note: The 23 citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of alfacalcidol for treating glucocorticoid-induced osteopenia patients with RA.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of adding a porous components to fixation of the tibial component for total knee replacement. There is a need for more well designed, adequately powered, high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine which components of porous components are the most appropriate for different types of fixation.

This review found no evidence to support the use of amiloride for the treatment of infective exacerbations associated with cystic fibrosis. However, the small number of participants included in the studies and the small sample sizes limit the usefulness of this review. Amiloride appears to have a beneficial effect on FEV1 in the short term but not in the longer term treatment period. Since nebulised amiloride has been shown to reduce infective exacerbations in cystic fibrosis, further trials are needed to assess its benefits and harms.

There is some evidence that automated protocols to achieve reducing the rate of reintubation after extubation failure in mechanically ventilated asthmatics and adult patients reduce the number of days of weaning durations within 48 hrs of time. There is a need for further well designed, conducted and reported randomised trials that evaluate the effect of automated protocols on the duration of mechanical ventilation and the incidence of post-extubation complications.

Evidence suggests that PEP mask therapy is an acceptable and effective alternative to other airway clearance techniques to improve lung function in people with cystic fibrosis, but the clinical significance of this is unclear. There is a need for more high quality randomised controlled trials investigating the long-term effects of different types of mask techniques on lung function, sputum production, symptom scores and quality of life.

Calcium supplementation during pregnancy reduces the risk of pre-eclampsia and preterm birth in healthy women. However, there was no evidence of a difference in maternal morbidity, maternal mortality or neonatal mortality when compared to placebo. There was no significant difference in neonatal outcome between women with calcium and placebo, and there was a non-significant trend towards a reduction in early preterm birth.
[Note: The 17 citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of influenza vaccine as a strategy to reduce the risk of zoster in high-risk populations. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with adequate numbers of patients.

The available evidence suggests that antidepressants are more effective than placebo in the acute treatment of major depressive disorder for preventing adverse events, including nausea, dry mouth, vomiting, endocrine, and irritability. Adverse events occurred more frequently among duloxetine-treated patients than placebo, but with a number needed to treat for less than 100 mg/day. There is no evidence to suggest that duloxetine is associated with better or worse efficacy than other antidepressants in terms of lower rates of discontinuation due to adverse events; efficacy end-points did not reach significance based on the global F test for controlling completed the acute phase of treatment.

There is no evidence to support the routine use of sertindole in the treatment of schizophrenia. There is a need for more high quality, well conducted and reported long-term randomised controlled trials with sufficient number of participants to determine the safety and efficacy of sertindole for people with schizophrenia.

This review provides some evidence that prednisolone pre-treatment is more effective than interferon alpha alone for the treatment of hepatitis B e antigen in children and young people. However, there is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of this drug over interferon alone. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this treatment.

The results of this review do not provide sufficient evidence to support or refute the use of ceftazidime as a first-line antibiotic for neonatal sepsis and infections in neonates. Ceftazidime plus clavulanic acid may be effective in reducing neonatal mortality and late neonatal infections, but it is unclear if penicillin and gentamicin are used as a broad-spectrum antibiotic for these infections. There is a need for well designed, conducted and reported randomised clinical trials with adequate numbers of neonates that evaluate the effect of beta-blockers compared to standard antibiotic regimes.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support the routine use of peripherally inserted PN in neonates with very low birthweight. There is no clear evidence that PN using CVC reduces the number of painful IV procedures and the length of intensive care stay in the neonatal intensive care unit. Further well-designed randomised trials are required to determine the relative effectiveness of this intervention in neonates.

There is some evidence that school based safety interventions can reduce the incidence and severity of burn injuries in children and adolescents when compared to standard care. However, it is not clear whether they can be effective in improving safety practices. There is a need for further well designed, conducted and reported studies that evaluate the effectiveness of different types of safety interventions.
[Note: The three citations in the awaiting classification section of this review may alter the conclusions of the review once assessed.]

Sodium valproate is an effective prophylactic treatment for migraine and is generally well tolerated. Adverse events were similar in the two groups treated with both valproate and placebo. There is insufficient evidence to determine which drugs are the most effective for the treatment of migraine, or for the long-term, safety and efficacy of these drugs.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine whether any specific preparation is more effective than any other for preventing or treating post-surgical ablation in patients with differentiated thyroid cancer. There is a need for well designed, adequately powered, high quality randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine the optimal preparation for postoperative ablation in low-risk patients.

This review suggests that certain types of antiviral agents have been shown to reduce the risk of CMV disease after kidney transplantation. Cytomegalovirus prophylaxis should be considered in high-risk recipients who are at risk for developing CMV disease, and who are prophylactically treated with routine use of routine anti-CD-3 therapy. In addition, there is insufficient evidence to support routine prophylaxis with other antiviral agents.

There is some evidence that the prevalence of aesthetically important dental fluorosis is low in children aged 7 years or more. There is no clear evidence that they may be associated with a higher level of exposure to fluoride exposure. Further research is needed to assess the relationship between different types of toothpaste and the prevalence and severity of dental fluorosis.

The single dose of paracetamol 650 mg is an effective analgesic in moderate to severe postoperative pain, with comparable efficacy to that of paracetamol 1000 mg when compared to ibuprofen 650 mg. All three doses were commonly used for postoperative pain relief, but the clinical significance of this is unclear. The combination of paracetamol 400 mg and nifedipine 1000 mg did not differ significantly from that of acetaminophen 1000 mg for pain relief up to six hours after the onset of action. Ibuprofen 25 mg is more effective than nifedipine 400 mg, and is associated with fewer adverse effects than paracetamol 1,000 mg. There was no statistically significant difference in efficacy between the two doses in terms of duration of action, time to meaningful analgesia, patient satisfaction, quality of life and costs.

There is some evidence to support the use of computer-based visual needs training as a supplement to standard therapy for certain types of vision restoration. However, it is not clear which type of training is the most effective for this purpose. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to evaluate the effect of different types of training on vision restoration in people with vascular disease.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of D-penicillamine to prevent retinopathy of prematurity in treated infants.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support or refute the use of preoperative skin traction for the treatment of acute non-ST hip fractures. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed, adequately powered randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this intervention.

Primary abortion regimens using mifepristone and misoprostol can be used from two to four days after mifepristone for medical abortion up to 13 weeks of pregnancy; (ii) vaginal misoprostol is the preferred prostaglandin that has been associated with fewer failures than either vaginal or oral misoprostol. There is no evidence of a difference in effectiveness or safety between the two drugs.

This review provides some evidence that the choice of topical or oral steroids is more effective than topical or systemic steroids for the initial treatment of acute otitis externa in adults and children. The choice of antibiotics and steroids should be considered as standard treatment options for the treatment of this common and important clinical condition.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of antibiotic prophylaxis for the treatment of acute traumatic pneumo forms. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this treatment.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of health promotion approaches to reduce eating disturbance and behaviour in young people. More research is needed on the long-term effects of these interventions.

In preterm infants with chronic lung disease, nebulised and intravenous frusemide did not result in a statistically significant decrease in the likelihood of airway resistance. There is no clear evidence that nebulised or intravenous frusemide improves pulmonary function for up to two hours after its administration. More research is needed to assess the effect of nebulised or inhaled frusemide on airway resistance and pulmonary mechanics in ventilated preterm infants.

There is no evidence to support the routine use of sibling in patients with pre- and probiotics following liver transplantation to reduce mortality, morbidity or hospitalisation in the short-term post-operative bacterial infection rate. However, these findings should be interpreted with caution due to the small number of trials included in this review.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of occupational therapy for patients with stroke and mobility. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up.

This review provides no convincing evidence that the combination of TAM and MPA is superior to TAM alone for treating women with advanced or recurrent endometrial cancer in terms of survival or progression-free survival. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine the optimal timing and type of treatment for this condition.
There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support or refute the use of any one intervention for the treatment of tetanus.

Adult identity mentoring can be effective in reducing the onset of sexual behaviour in young children and adolescents, but there is insufficient evidence to support or refute its use. There is a need for further high-quality research into the effectiveness of these interventions, particularly when implemented in diverse communities.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of NCPAP as a treatment for RDS after extubation in very low birth weight infants. Further trials are needed to determine which NCPAP is the most effective repair for RDS and the optimal timing of synchronized ventilation.

This review provides some evidence that high-dose fentanyl versus low-dose opioid anaesthesia of epidural analgesia reduces the risk of episodic and late postoperative hypoxemia in patients undergoing elective coronary artery bypass grafting. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine which method of analgesia is the most effective, safe and effective in terms of reducing postoperative pain, myocardial ischaemia and patient satisfaction. These findings should be interpreted with caution due to the small number of studies included in this review and the small numbers of participants and participants included in the meta-analysis.
There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of selenium supplements to reduce the risk of preterm birth and infant death among HIV-1 disease-infected pregnant women.

Oral probiotics reduces the incidence of NEC and NEC (>or in very low birth weight neonates. However, there is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of probiotics as a supplement to enteral feeding in neonatal intensive care. There is no evidence to suggest that probiotics should be given to reducing NEC in preterm infants.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the routine volume of fluid therapy after aneurysmal subarachnoid haemorrhage. Further well designed RCTs are required to determine whether or not fluid therapy reduces the risk of vasospasm after haemorrhage. There is a need for further high quality RCTs to investigate the role of fluid prophylaxis in preventing vasospasm in patients with either persistent or advanced haemorrhage.

There is insufficient evidence to guide any recommendations for practice. Large, better designed studies are needed in order to evaluate the use of any effective intervention for preventing CHF and its complications.

Evidence suggests that antifungal drugs are more effective than fluconazole or placebo for the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis and temporarily in HIV-positive patients. However, it is not clear whether this is superior to placebo in preventing the recurrence of candidiasis in HIV/AIDS. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the optimal dosing regimen for this condition.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of topical oxideides to reduce the development of dental caries in children and adolescents. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed clinical trials with long-term follow-up to assess the effects of the various application of oxideides.

There is some evidence that outreach visits alone or in combination with a training workshop reduced the use of targeted drugs in certain ethnic groups for the diagnosis of acute asthma, but there was no evidence that they may be beneficial for the management of this condition. There is insufficient evidence to support the effectiveness of outreach visits as a means to reduce the uptake of care for patients with acute asthma. More research is needed on the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of outreach compared with usual care or usual care alone.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of physical therapy for cardiovascular fitness in people with stroke. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with adequate power to evaluate the benefits and harms of this intervention.

Rhythm appears to reduce the risk of stroke or death in patients with non-malignant atrial fibrillation. However, it does not seem to offer any advantage over the rate-control therapy in terms of reducing the incidence of hospital admission or any other adverse event profile.

There is no evidence to support the routine use of chemotherapy in the treatment of locally advanced head and neck cancer. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed RCTs with long-term follow up to determine the optimal dose and duration of chemotherapy.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of intraocular lidocaine as a supplement to topical anaesthesia for phacoemulsification surgery. There is some evidence that intraocular lidocaine is superior to placebo in preventing intraoperative pain during phacoemulsification, but there is no evidence that it improves satisfaction with the administration of topical anaesthesia. More research is needed on the long-term effectiveness and safety of these drugs.

The available evidence suggests that long-term antibiotic prophylaxis with ciprofloxacin is more effective than placebo for the prevention of bacterial peritonitis in patients with liver-negative bacilli levels (<15 g/L. Until is associated with a higher incidence of bacterial sepsis and gastrointestinal bleeding. Until should not be used outside randomised clinical trials.

Oral zinc is effective in reducing the occurrence of visual loss in the short term in the age-related macular degeneration. There is insufficient evidence to support routine antioxidant supplementation to prevent the progression of the disease in patients with AMD. Further research is needed to assess the long-term effects of vitamin E, minerals, vitamins and minerals, and its use in the treatment of AMD.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of tranexamic acid as a supplement to reduce bleeding resulting immediately post-stroke from the end of spontaneous delivery and to reduce blood loss immediately post CS. There is no clear evidence that tranexamic acid has a beneficial effect on blood loss. Large, well designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up are necessary to determine whether tranexamic acid should be used for the prevention and treatment of blood loss after spontaneous delivery.

There is some evidence that cervical cytology techniques are more effective than standard sampling techniques in terms of reducing the number of repeat smears required and the numbers of abnormal cytology. There is no clear evidence that the presence of endocervical cells in the form of cervical cytology is better than the cotton swab, but there is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of a memoryre. More research is needed on the significance of the superiority of different methods and the relationship between superiority and clinical outcomes.

There is no evidence to support or refute the use of synthetic surfactant protein containing phospholipids for preventing the incidence of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) and RDS, compared with animal-derived products. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine which synthetic protein is the most effective treatment for this group. Further well designed randomised controlled trials are needed to determine the optimal synthetic protein margin for the prevention and treatment of RDS in preterm infants.

There is insufficient evidence to determine which method of treatment is the most appropriate for treating patients with low-risk prostatic cancer. Further randomised clinical trials with long term follow up are required.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support the use of laser and ultrasound for treating pressure ulcers. There is a need for well-designed, adequately powered, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCTs to address the efficacy of these interventions in the management of pressure ulcers in adults. A large scale methodologically rigorous randomised controlled trial is needed to assess the effectiveness of different types of laser versus no treatment.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of oral pilocarpine as a treatment for the treatment of post-licic xerostomia in patients with head and neck cancer. There is no clear evidence that pilocarpine is an effective treatment for patients with non-specific radiation-induced xerostomia. However, this conclusion is limited by the small number of trials included in this review, small sample sizes and small numbers of participants.

There is no evidence to support the routine use of IV cyclosporine as a single treatment for patients with severe ulcerative colitis refractory to corticosteroids. There is a need for more randomized clinical trials with larger patient populations to evaluate the effects of this treatment.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine which method of treatment is the most appropriate for severe NPSLE in adults. Further well-designed, adequately powered randomised clinical trials are required.

This review provides some evidence that breastfeeding support for lactating mothers of preterm infants using the breast pump is more effective than the electric breast pump. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine which type of breastfeeding is the most effective and safe for lactating infants. Further research is needed to assess the benefits and harms associated with the choice of such intervention.

Zinc supplementation with zinc, or with or without copper, is effective in reducing the incidence of symptomatic and secondary episodes of diarrhoea and pneumonia in children aged 6 to 12 months to young children. There is no evidence to suggest that zinc supplementation increases the risk of pneumonia or episodes of other respiratory tract infections, but further research is needed to determine whether the benefits are due to differences in zinc intake.

There is no evidence that intramuscular morphine is an effective analgesic for postoperative pain relief after total knee replacement, but the clinical significance of this is unclear. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this technique.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of surgery for patients with acute limb ischaemia. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials assessing the benefits and harms associated with surgery for these patients.
[Note: The four citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of 5% albumin as a first-line treatment for hypotension in neonates. There is some evidence that the volume of the colloid infused is more effective than isotonic albumin in increasing hypotension in the first 48 hours of life and there is no evidence that it may be superior to the control for preventing hypotension. However, there is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to assess the effect of different types of calcium infused on important short-term outcomes such as death, lung function, quality of life, mortality and morbidity.

There is no direct comparison of treatment duration with terbinafine and griseofulvin for the treatment of tinea capitis. Terbinafine was significantly more effective than terbinafine at higher doses than griseofulvin. There was no evidence of a difference in the risk of adverse events between different methods of therapy. There is a need for further well designed, adequately powered randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine the optimal dose and duration of treatment for tinea capitis in children.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of benzydamine hydrochloride spray as an effective post-tonsillectomy analgesic for reducing postoperative pain after tonsillectomy.
