There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed and reported randomised controlled trials with adequate power to assess the effect of this intervention on postoperative pain.
There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support the use of surgical fixation in adults with displaced fractures of the neck of the femur.

There is some evidence that preoperative inpatient hospital stay with respect to hospital at home reduces the length of hospital stay after primary or secondary hip and knee replacement surgery, but there is no evidence that patients who cannot function at home may benefit from inpatient hospital care without compromising patient outcomes. There is a need for more high quality research in this area.

There is no evidence to support the routine use of zinc supplementation for people with sickle cell disease. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised clinical trials with low risk of bias to determine whether zinc is beneficial or harmful for the treatment of people with SCD.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of any type of wound dressing for the treatment of foot ulcers. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow-up.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine which methods of surgery are the most appropriate for treating middle-aged fractures of the humerus. There is a need for high quality, well-designed randomised clinical trials with long-term outcomes that compare different types of fixation, types of nail and intramedullary nails versus another forms of fixation.
[Note: The 23 citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions drawn from the review once assessed.]

There is no clear evidence that MTX is an effective treatment for disease activity in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Leflunomide appears to be more effective than MTX at the expense of gastrointestinal symptoms, nausea and gastrointestinal side effects, and is associated with fewer side effects than MTX. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed trials that evaluate the efficacy of MTX in the treatment of patients with RA.
There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support the routine use of biofeedback for the treatment of pain during childbirth.

This review found no evidence to support the routine use of oral glatiramer acetate for the treatment of primary relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this treatment.

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is associated with significantly shorter hospital stay and shorter time to full work compared with open cholecystectomy. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy may be associated with fewer acute postoperative complications and reduced hospital stay, but there is no evidence of a difference in the length of hospital stay when compared with the general use of minilaparotomy cholecystectomy. There is a need for further well designed randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from the laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the effectiveness of the best materials to improve the process-of-care indicators for pre-publicized risk-based behaviour in Medicaid. However, there is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials to determine whether the information is effective in reducing the risk of death or death-related problems due to medical problems such as healthcare professionals, medical conditions and healthcare providers. More research is needed to assess the effects of the information on health-related quality of life and patient outcomes.

This updated meta-analysis showed that neoadjuvant chemotherapy compared with surgery alone for patients with resectable oesophageal cancer improved tumour response and progression-free survival compared to surgery alone. There was no evidence of a difference in OS between the two approaches. However, these results should be interpreted with caution due to the small number of included trials and the heterogeneity of the trials.

There is some evidence that the use of motivational interviewing for the prevention of tobacco initiation reduces the uptake of smoking by children. However, this conclusion is limited by the small number of studies included in the meta-analysis and small numbers of studies, the methodological shortcomings in the design of intervention trials and the small sample sizes of the studies. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials that test the effectiveness of this intervention in preventing tobacco initiation among low-income children.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of oral salbutamol as a bronchodilator treatment for acute wheeze in infants. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to evaluate the efficacy of this therapy.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of galantamine for maintenance of cognitive function in patients with Alzheimer's disease plus cerebrovascular disease.

Many trials are required to establish its efficacy on the intensity and duration of migraine prophylaxis, the number of days with migraine, the rate of rescue medication use and the safety of treatment.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of a Mediterranean diet to treat patients with rheumatoid arthritis. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials that examine the effect of an artificial diet on disease activity outcomes in patients with RA.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the routine use of melatonin in treating patients with acute or chronic AMD. The data from this review do not provide sufficient evidence that it may be a useful first-line treatment for some patients with AMD. There is a need for further well designed, adequately powered RCTs to investigate the effect of this treatment on patient-important outcomes.

Nurse management programmes for patients discharged from hospital following admission for congestive heart failure reduced all-cause and HF readmission rates and reduced hospital admission and hospital stay. However, there was no evidence of a difference in mortality rates between the intervention and control groups. There was a significant increase in the number of days in hospital readmissions seen in the emergency department and the total number of emergency department days required by patients in the intervention group. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up that evaluate the benefits and harms associated with the routine use of these interventions.

There is insufficient evidence to determine the optimal duration of oral anticoagulation following a first episode of venous thromboembolism to reduce the risk of recurrent VTE and major bleeding. There is some evidence that a high rate of major bleeding was significantly more common after six months of anticoagulation compared to one year following randomization, but this was not statistically significant and was associated with a higher risk of major haemorrhage.

There is some evidence that moderate-quality physical activity programmes can produce significant benefits in reducing pain, increasing function and improve quality of life for people with lower limb OA. There is a need for further high-quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the effectiveness of these interventions.

At present, there is insufficient evidence to support the use of EMG biofeedback as an effective treatment for the functional recovery of the hemiplegic limb after stroke.
[Note: The 13 citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of lithium as a supplement to haloperidol for the treatment of bipolar disorder. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow-up.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of universal-designed interventions for type 2 diabetes mellitus. However, there is some evidence that these interventions are associated with a significant improvements in HbA1c, fasting glucose, lipids, blood pressure, and insulin. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine the safety and efficacy of these interventions.

This review provides some evidence that vitamin A supplementation to mother and child infants reduced the risk of stillbirth and stillbirth-related death compared with no intervention. However, there was no evidence of benefit for stillbirth, but this was not associated with a higher risk of live birth. Vitamin A supplementation appears to be beneficial in reducing stillbirth and may be considered for infants less than 5-6 mo mo of age. Further trials are needed to assess the effects of vitamin A on stillbirth and other maternal and infant outcomes including caregiver mortality.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine whether laser therapy is more effective than serial CCTioreduction for women with presumed twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome before 26 weeks of gestation.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of prophylactic epidermal devices for chronic and subacute LBP in adults with low-back pain. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed and reported RCTs that compare the effectiveness of these interventions, especially in combination with pharmacological treatment, in terms of reducing intensity of pain, intensity of chronic LBP and reducing short-term duration of pain after the procedure.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of intrathecal morphine as a treatment for cancer pain due to the lack of high-quality evidence from randomised controlled trials. There is a clear need for well designed, adequately powered, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCTs to assess the efficacy and safety of this drug in this patient population.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of orientation letter for reducing missed initial appointments in a community mental health center. There is a need for well designed, adequately powered randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up.

There is no clear evidence that antenatal visits reduced infant and maternal morbidity and mortality for low-risk women compared with the traditional prenatal care visit schedule. Women should be informed that there are no clear differences between the two types of visits when compared to the standard schedule. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials that examine the effectiveness of different types of antenatal care.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of anticoagulants to reduce the risk of death from any cause of ischaemic events after stroke in patients with transient ischaemic attack or stroke due to presumed arterial stenosis of a major intracranial artery.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of ticlopidine as a treatment for the prevention of graft thrombosis in patients with established end-stage renal failure. However, there is some evidence that ticlopidine has a beneficial effect on the occurrence of major major bleeding in these patients.
[Note: The four citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

NBI appears to improve colonic polyps rates by reducing the number of adenomas/total number of patients. However, there is insufficient evidence to support the use of narrow band imaging to reduce the incidence of adverse events. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to assess the effect of narrow-band imaging on colonic polyps.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support the routine use of H1ift for the treatment of chronic asthma in adults. Oxatomide should not be used for treating children with chronic asthma.

Estrogen is effective in reducing the risk of cognitive decline in postmenopausal women with a history of dementia, MCI and mild cognitive impairment. However, we found no consistent evidence that the addition of progestin to estrogen has a positive effect on the cognitive function measures of postmenopausal women. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow-up to determine the effects of specific types of progestin treatment on cognition, cognitive function, mood and mental state in women aged 65 years or older.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of oxygen supplementation in the management of people with COPD in terms of improving quality of life or improving core outcomes. There is a need for more randomized controlled clinical trials with long-term follow up to assess the effects of this intervention.

Prophylactic ganciclovir significantly reduced the incidence of CMV disease and disease-related CMV disease when compared with placebo in liver-transplant recipients. However, it seemed to reduce the risk of allograft rejection and disease without affecting the survival rate of either grafts or patients.
[Note: The eight citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of intramuscular clonidine as an effective treatment for neonatal withdrawal syndrome. There is some evidence that intramuscular clonidine may reduce the incidence of adverse cardiovascular outcomes in infants exposed to methadone and/or heroin, but there is no evidence that it may be beneficial or harmful for improving developmental outcomes.
[Note: The three citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of this review once assessed.]

There is some evidence that antihypertensive agents based on calcium antagonists reduce the risk of all-cause and cardiovascular mortality when compared with placebo in patients with pre-existing hypertension and hypertensive patients. There is no evidence that these drugs are associated with an increased risk of major vascular events, but this was not associated with a higher risk of fatal and nonfatal myocardial infarction, stroke, or hospitalized angina than with diuretics. The results of this review support the use of calcium antagonists as a first-line antihypertensive agent for the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality in high-risk patients.

Chemical plexus plexus block is an effective analgesic for treating pain due to unresectable pancreatic cancer. However, there is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of this intervention as a treatment for this condition. There is no clear evidence that it is associated with a higher rate of adverse effects, such as nausea, vomiting, one abscess, and nausea and/or nausea and opioids.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of high-dose chemotherapy as adjuvant therapy for women with high-risk breast cancer and multiple lymph nodes. There is some evidence that adjuvant chemotherapy plus stem cell transplantation improves disease-free survival and overall survival in women with a extensive axillary lymph nodes of the tumour-positive infraclavicular lymph nodes caused by estrogen receptor cells.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of inhaled salbutamol as a treatment for cough in children and their carers. Large, well-designed, multicentre, double-blind RCTs are required to assess the effects of salbutamol or other airway obstruction treatments for children with recurrent cough.

This review provides some evidence that the addition of NSAIDs or anti-inflammatory drugs to paracetamol or diclofenac increases the risk of postoperative pain outcomes in children undergoing extractions of primary teeth. There is no clear evidence that any one surgical intervention was superior to the other. Small sample sizes and differences in study design limit the usefulness of this intervention in determining the most effective analgesic in preventing postoperative pain in children.

Rofecoxib is an effective oral dose for the treatment of moderate to severe acute postoperative pain. Rofecoxib was associated with fewer gastrointestinal and nervous system adverse events. Adverse effects were uncommon, though post-extraction alveolitis (dry socket) occurred more often with rofecoxib than placebo, and gastrointestinal adverse events were more common with both active and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of exercise for preventing the development of IGT in people with impaired glucose tolerance. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed and reported randomised controlled trials to determine the effect of exercise versus no intervention on the long-term morbidity and mortality among people with IGT.
[Note: The four citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

For ventilated neonates with CLD, the prone position is a safe and effective procedure for short-term effects on respiratory rate, heart rate, respiratory complications and oxygen desaturation. The mechanism and clinical applicability of such trials need to be explored further. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine which method of position is the most appropriate for ventilated neonates.

There is some evidence that the body-worn device is more effective than placebo for the treatment of children with monosymptomatic primary nocturnal enuresis. There is insufficient evidence to determine which type of choice is the most effective treatment for children with wetting. The effectiveness of alarms for these children remains uncertain. The results of this review do not provide sufficient evidence to support the use of alarms as an effective treatment to treat wetting.

There is no clear evidence that cord clamping reduces infant haematological status in term infants 24- to 72- months after birth. However, there is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of this procedure to reduce infant anaemia. There is a need for further high-quality randomised controlled trials to assess the benefits and harms of cord clamping.
[Note: The 23 citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of generic review once assessed.]

Zomepirac 30 mg has been shown to be effective at treating moderate to severe acute postoperative pain after the removal of unilateral third molar teeth under local anaesthesia. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine which method of analgesic efficacy is the most appropriate for the treatment of postoperative pain.

There is currently no evidence to support or refute the use of macrolides in treating children with severe asthma. There is a need for more high quality, well designed RCTs that compare macrolides with methylprednisolone and in combination with methylprednisolone alone. Further well-designed, adequately powered RCTs are required to assess the effect of macrolides on exacerbations and control of asthma in children.
[Note: The six citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the new review once assessed.]

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of a leaflet for improving adherence to post-exposure prophylaxis after rape. There is a need for well designed, conducted and reported randomised controlled trials with adequate power to evaluate the effect of leaflet for preventing or treating HIV transmission after the rape.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support the routine use of LUNA as an effective treatment for women with severe midline dysmenorrhea undergoing first-line surgical procedures for symptomatic endometriosis. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine the optimal management of this condition.

This review suggests that there is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of CBZ-controlled release carbamazepine as a treatment for epilepsy. There is no evidence to suggest that carbamazepine is associated with a higher rate of seizure frequency, a lower rate of re-intubation, or a higher level of serum CBZ concentration. The quality of the evidence was generally poor and the confidence intervals were too wide to be confident that they did not differ significantly between the two drugs.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support or refute the use of thalidomide in the treatment of active Crohn's disease. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCTs to assess the efficacy and safety of thalidomide.

The present systematic review suggests that methadone is an effective maintenance treatment for opioid dependence as it is not associated with better outcomes than no treatment. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine which type of maintenance is most effective and which is associated with improved retention. There is a need for more high quality trials investigating the long-term efficacy of methadone in the management of opioid dependence.
[Note: The 23 citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

Adjuvant adjuvant chemotherapy for high-grade soft tissue sarcomas of the head and neck does not seem to offer a statistically significant advantage in terms of disease-free survival, local recurrence, and overall survival when compared with no treatment or with chemotherapy alone. Due to the small number of trials included in this review, it is not possible to recommend the use of platinum-based chemotherapy for these patients.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of HT to reduce vertebral vertebral fractures in women with a history of CHD. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials that examine the effects of HT on vertebral and hip fractures in postmenopausal women. The results of this review should be interpreted cautiously because of the short duration of the trials and the lack of reporting of adverse effects in many of the included trials.

This review provides some evidence that the use of lidocaine in the endotracheal tube cuff is associated with a reduction in sore throat and a decrease in the incidence of postoperative sore throat. However, there is insufficient evidence to support its use in the routine use of this form of route to reduce the risk of postoperative airway symptoms.

There is some evidence that biofeedback exercises may be more effective than placebo exercises in the short-term treatment of patellofemoral pain syndrome. However, there is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of biofeedback exercises as a treatment for patellofemoral pain. There is a need for more high quality, well designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to evaluate the benefits and harms of this intervention.

There is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of calcium-blocking agents in the treatment of Duchenne muscular dystrophy. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCTs to determine whether or not the calcium-containing agent is effective.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of foot reflexology in pregnancy to reduce ankle and foot oedema as a measure of wellbeing in pregnancy.

Alvimopan reduces gastrointestinal transit time and improves the return of gastrointestinal function in the first 48 hours after drug administration of opioid administration in patients with opioid-induced constipation. There was no evidence of a difference in efficacy between different doses of opioids, but these results were not statistically significant. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow-up to evaluate the effect of opioids on gastrointestinal transit.
There is insufficient evidence to support routine preoperative medical testing before cataract surgery for reducing the rate of medical complications.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of pre-emptive infiltration with bupivacaine as an effective analgesic in the control of postoperative pain after tonsillectomy. There is some evidence that bupivacaine is superior to placebo in reducing postoperative pain for adult patients undergoing tonsillectomy, but this may be due to the small number of patients enrolled in the trials.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of shoulder strapping as an effective treatment to prevent post-stroke pain after stroke. Large, high quality, randomised controlled trials are required to determine the relative benefits and harms of this intervention.

The pooled sensitivity and specificity of Xpert MTB/RIF for diagnostic performance for TB and HIV-positive detection remains unproven. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed, adequately powered, well conducted and reported long-term randomised controlled trials that examine the effect of different methods of standard culture and culture-positive TB tests.
[Note: The 23 citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

There is insufficient evidence to determine whether propranolol is effective in the treatment of neuroleptic-induced akathisia in people with schizophrenia. Large, well-designed and reported randomised controlled trials are required to assess the effects of propranolol as an adjunct to anticholinergic medication in the management of this condition in a patient population.

This review provides some evidence that educational interventions can be effective in enhancing screening and performance of a variety of screening tests for men with a strong suspicion of breast cancer. More research is needed on the long-term effects of different delivery methods, such as decision aids, in terms of patient satisfaction, decisional conflict, and time spent discussing screening. There is a need for further well designed, conducted and reported pragmatic randomised controlled trials to evaluate the effects of educational interventions on the performance of these tests in shared decision making. The findings of this review should be interpreted with caution due to the small number of women included in the trials and the small sample sizes of the trials.

There is no evidence to support the use of a pill containing the same dose of the same type of progestin compound for treating premenopausal women with premenopausal users. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow-up to determine which contraceptive products are the most effective, safe and effective in preventing premenopausal users' BMD.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of beta-blockers for treating intermittent claudication. There is a need for high quality, adequately powered, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCTs to determine the effects of this intervention on quality of life, symptoms and exercise heart rate.
[Note: The 23 citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of how best to deliver the review once assessed.]

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of sublingual nitroglycerin as a treatment for the removal of placenta. Sublingual nitroglycerin may be effective in reducing birth weight rates for women with placenta, but further studies are needed to confirm this.

Parental presence during induction of anaesthesia reduces preoperative anxiety in children undergoing surgery and is associated with improved health-related quality of life. There is no evidence that preoperative anxiety may be reduced by parental oral midazolam or oral sedatives. However, it does not appear to significantly reduce the incidence of emergence delirium when compared to no intervention. Further research is needed to assess the effect of preoperative anxiety on multiple measures such as child's fears and behaviour.

There is insufficient evidence to determine which method of treatment is the most appropriate for people with congenital hypothyroidism. However, there is a need for well designed, adequately powered, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCTs to assess the efficacy and safety of adding initial T4 to people with severe hypothyroidism to reduce the time to reach target T4 normalization in thyroid function. Further well-designed, high quality randomised controlled trials are needed to determine whether initial L-thyroxine doses are more efficacious than no treatment for these people.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of melatonin as monotherapy for typical absence seizures in children and young people. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCTs to determine whether melatonin is effective in reducing the frequency of seizure frequency in people with epilepsy.

The findings of this review support the use of low-intensity, functionally oriented exercise programmes to reduce urinary incontinence in frail nursing home residents. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials that examine the effects of such programmes.

Based on the results of this systematic review, we cannot provide no evidence to support the routine use of a cholesterol-lowering agent for treating people with intermittent claudication. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed, long-term randomised controlled trials investigating the effect of statins on cardiovascular outcomes in this patient population.

There is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of IVRO techniques for the treatment of dyspareunia fixation in adults with dyspareunia fixation. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed and reported randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up.

The available evidence suggests that pre-exposure prophylaxis with immune serum globulin is effective in preventing infectious hepatitis A infection. However, the number of studies included was too small to allow reliable conclusions to be drawn about the relative effectiveness of the two types of prophylaxis.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of dorsal nerve block as an effective analgesic for postoperative analgesia in children undergoing circumcision. There is a need for more randomized clinical trials with larger sample sizes that this technique is associated with higher rates of side effects and side effects due to adverse events. However, this conclusion is limited by the small number of studies included in this review, small numbers of participants and lack of reporting of outcome data. Further well-designed, adequately powered RCTs are required to determine which analgesic techniques are the most effective for post-operative analgesia in people undergoing circumcision for religious reasons.

This review provides some evidence that salmeterol and fluticasone are effective in reducing exacerbations and lung function in moderate to severe COPD, but there is no evidence that they are associated with an increased risk of side effects. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the optimal dose and duration of treatment for the treatment of COPD.

There is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of bleomycin as a treatment for patients with craniopharynoprophylaxis systems. There is a need for more studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow up to determine which methodologically sound differences between the benefits and harms of the various types of therapy.

In women with endometriosis, a GnRH agonist 0.15 mg daily is effective at preventing bone loss up to two years after GnRH agonist treatment. However, it does not seem to reduce the risk of dysmenorrhoea. There is no evidence to suggest that GnRHas is effective in the treatment of bone loss induced by the cessation of treatment, and add-on therapy is associated with an improvement in dysmenorrhoea. In the short-term, there was a small but statistically significant reduction in dysmenorrhoea in women treated with GnRHas, but this was not consistently associated with a significant increase in bone mass.
[Note: The 15 citations in the awaiting classification section may alter the conclusions of the review once assessed.]

This review provides some evidence that providing patients with the audiotaped initial consultation using an self-efficacy tape to support the provision of information provided by healthcare professionals leads to improved their perception of being informed about treatment decisions and their levels of anxiety and depression. There is a need for further well designed, conducted and reported long-term randomised controlled trials that evaluate the effects of such interventions on patient satisfaction, health-related quality of life and health related costs.

Local corticosteroids are effective in relieving symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome, but there is insufficient evidence to support its use in the short-term treatment of this condition. There is some evidence that corticosteroids are more effective than placebo or no treatment when compared with other interventions, and it is less clear than full-time corticosteroids. The studies included in this review were of short duration, with follow-up seven months. The findings of this review suggest that most of the studies were at risk of bias, and that results from the available data do not support the use of corticosteroids in reducing symptoms such as motor nerve conduction, wrist symptoms, or functional impairment in patients with CTS.

Fluoxetine and psychotherapy are effective in reducing eating and depression of inpatients with bulimia nervosa, but the clinical significance remains unclear. There is a need for more studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods to determine the relative effectiveness of these interventions. Further research is needed to assess the long-term effects of different types of psychotherapy and treatments including antidepressant medication, medication alone, and medication combined with medication in combination with psychological therapy in the treatment of bulimia nervosa.

Tinidazole given to every 100 people undergoing appendectomy is effective in reducing the incidence of post-abdominal infections and reducing the rate of infection requiring hospital stay in people undergoing appendicectomy; however, they did not reduce the risk of infection severity. There is insufficient evidence to determine which type of antibiotic prophylaxis is the most appropriate for patients.

There is no clear evidence that manual therapy is an effective treatment for acute and subacute LBP, but there is some evidence that it is more effective than other forms of manual therapy. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the relative effectiveness of these interventions.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of dehydroepiandrosteroneepiandrosterone as an effective antipsychotic treatment for people with schizophrenia. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed, long-term randomised controlled trials that examine the efficacy and safety of this augmentation in this patient population.

In patients with refractory bone pain due to prostatic cancer, clodronate significantly reduced the risk of pain scores more than placebo, but there was no evidence of benefit in terms of decreasing vomiting, pain relief, and analgesic use. There was no statistically significant difference between the two drugs. There is insufficient evidence to support the use of oral clodronate for treating refractory pain from prostatic cancer.
[Note: The 24 citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

Compared with placebo, 5-ASA appears to be as effective as oral tongue in the treatment of mild to moderate distal active UC. However, there is some evidence that they are effective in the short term, but are associated with fewer adverse events. There is a need for further well designed, adequately powered, high quality randomised clinical trials with long-term follow-up.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of unobs for the treatment of recurrent glioblastoma. The available trial data do not provide sufficient evidence that unobs are effective in treating patients with high risk glioma. Further trials are needed to determine the effect of humidifierss on the survival of patients with unresectable brain or IV gliomas.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of benzodiazepines as a treatment for alcoholic withdrawal states. Large, well-designed and reported randomised controlled trials are needed to assess the effectiveness of benzodiazepines for alcoholic states.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of refractive correction for the treatment of moderate to severe amblyopia in children 7 to 12 years of age. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the effectiveness of these interventions.

There is no evidence to support the use of CIP in the treatment of infants with severe respiratory failure. There is a small but significant increase in the need for oxygen therapy for infants with respiratory disease who are at least 50% to 100 g at birth. The use of continuous positive end-expiratory pressure was associated with a reduction in the length of oxygen therapy, but there was no evidence of benefit in the incidence of pneumothorax or neonatal mortality.
[Note: The three citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

Oxacillin impregnated with antibiotics significantly reduces the risk of postoperative infection after insertion of a shunt for CSF drainage in children undergoing "clean "" operations of cerebrospinal fluid. There was no evidence of a difference in the rate of infection in areas with the use of antibiotics when compared to a single regimen.

Hydroxychloroquine has no benefit in treating chronic steroid dependent asthma. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine whether or not hydroxychloroquine is an effective treatment for these patients.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of rosuvastatin for the treatment of symptomatic VTE in apparently healthy men and women. Observational studies have yielded variable estimates of the effect of statin therapy on the risk of venous thromboembolism, and evidence from randomized trials is lacking.

Since the last version of this review no new studies have been found that the prophylactic prophylaxis of Mycobacterium avium complex infection in patients with advanced AIDS leads to a significant reduction in the risk of post-and M. avium complex disease and bacterial pneumonia. There was no evidence of a difference in the incidence of adverse events between prophylaxis with azithromycin and placebo. However, this conclusion is limited by the small number of included trials and the lack of reporting of adverse effects in many of the included trials. More well-designed, adequately powered, longer-term randomised controlled trials are needed to evaluate the effect of prophylactic prophylaxis with clarithromycin on long-term mortality and morbidity in adults with AIDS.

Prazosin and methyldopa are effective in reducing blood pressure in moderate hypertension, but the clinical significance remains unclear. Trimazosin, 900 mg daily, and methyldopa 2,250 mg daily are equally effective in lowering blood pressure and may be more effective than placebo, although there is insufficient evidence to support its use in the treatment of patients with essential hypertension. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, randomised controlled trials with long-term follow-up that test the efficacy of methyldopa as an isolated treatment for patients with mild to moderate hypertension.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the routine use of tamoxifen for treating patients with advanced hepatocellular carcinoma. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials that examine the long-term effects of tamoxifen on survival in this group of patients.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of nail-insertion techniques for the treatment of closed fractures of the tibial shaft fracture. There is some evidence that there are no major differences in delayed union rates between reamed and unreamed nails.

Rofecoxib and NSAIDs are effective in slow the progression of Alzheimer's disease and cognitive decline in patients with mild to moderate AD. There is insufficient evidence to support the use of NSAIDs as a treatment for the treatment of AD.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of nursing beds for primary care for critically ill patients. However, there is some evidence that post-acute care is effective in reducing length of hospital stay and improving healthcare costs, but the quality of the evidence was low. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised controlled trials that compare the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of different types of beds.

There is no evidence to support the routine use of candesartan for the treatment of microalbuminuria in normotensive patients with type 1 or type 2 diabetes. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials that examine the long-term effects of candesartan on patient-important outcomes in this population.

The findings of this review support the use of attachment-based family therapy as a treatment for mood episodes of bipolar I disorder. However, there is insufficient evidence to support or refute the effectiveness of this intervention. Further well-designed, adequately powered randomised controlled trials are needed.

The findings of this review suggest that self-help materials and behavioural interventions are effective in promoting smoking cessation and reduction for pregnant women. There is insufficient evidence to support the use of NRT as a behavioural intervention to help pregnant women quit during pregnancy and to increase the likelihood of quit in pregnancy. Women should be offered NRT as part of a standard intervention or usual care.

Cognitive-educational therapy is effective in reducing pain reduction in people with fibromyalgia, however there is some evidence that the addition of a cognitive component may be more effective than a waiting list control for the treatment of non-specific pain. There is no evidence to support the routine use of group cognitive/educational therapy as a treatment for patients with chronic pain.

There is insufficient evidence to recommend zuclopenthixol acetate as a supplement to conventional liquid oral haloperidol for the treatment of people with schizophrenia or schizophrenia-related symptoms. The available data do not support the use of zuclopenthixol acetate when compared to haloperidol in the short-term treatment of this condition. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed RCTs that compare zuclopenthixol acetate with other anti-inflammatory drugs, including benzodiazepines, for the initial treatment of those with schizophrenia.

There is some evidence to support routine salt restriction for two or three weeks to reduce the severity of asthma in people with chronic asthma. There is no clear evidence that increased salt intake reduces the incidence of asthma-related adverse events in asthmatics, but further studies are needed to confirm these findings.

There is some evidence that EA provides less analgesia to anaesthesia during oocyte aspiration, but there is no evidence of benefit for the other. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials that compare EA with other medical and anaesthesia methods for the induction of pain relief in the oocyte retrieval setting.

Famciclovir 800 mg daily is an effective treatment for acute herpes zoster, but the clinical significance of the disease is still unclear. There is insufficient evidence to determine whether or not acyclovir has any effect on chronic pain or post-surgical pain. Oral acyclovir had no statistically significant effect on the severity or duration of post-herpetic neuralgia. There was no difference in the incidence of adverse effects between the two placebos.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of manoeuvres as a strategy to reduce the risk of barotrauma in patients with acute lung injury or acute respiratory distress syndrome. There is some evidence that manoeuvres are more effective than low PEEP and high levels of positive end-expiratory pressure for the management of ALI/ARDS. There was no evidence of a difference in barotrauma rates between the two types of manoeuvres. Further research is needed.

This review provides some evidence that ultrasound guidance during embryo transfer improves clinical pregnancy and live birth rates in IVF cycles. There was no evidence of a difference in clinical pregnancy rates for ultrasound-guided embryo transfer compared with clinical touch transfer.

This review provides some evidence that topical corticosteroids are more effective than placebo for the treatment of CRS. There is insufficient evidence to support the use of topical corticosteroids in the management of CRS, and further high quality trials are needed to determine the optimal type and duration of treatment. Topical corticosteroids should not be considered when given before and after sinus surgery for patients with CRS.
[Note: The 15 citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of review once assessed.]

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of dipyrone as an effective treatment for acute migraine pain, pain relief or symptom control in people with episodic tension-type headaches. The trials included in this review were of poor quality and used a relatively small number of participants, so no conclusions can be drawn about the effectiveness of this drug.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support or refute the use of nutrition screening programmes for reducing the number of short and long-term nutritional episodes and the likelihood of hearing loss among adults in the general population. Further well-designed, high quality RCTs are needed.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of any treatment for alcoholic hepatic encephalopathy in patients with moderate to severe disease. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine which preparations are the most effective treatment for these patients.

We found no evidence to support the use of antifibrinolytic antifibrinolytic agents to reduce blood loss during scoliosis surgery. Aprotinin may reduce the need for autologous blood transfusions in patients with scoliosis, but the clinical significance remains unclear. Aprotinin is associated with a higher rate of thrombotic morbidity and a lower risk of transfusion requirements. Further research is needed to assess the effect of antifibrinolytic agents on reducing blood loss and transfusion requirements in patients undergoing scoliosis surgery and to determine the optimal management of these patients.

This review suggests that there is insufficient evidence to support the use of chemotherapeutic corticosteroids in conventional dosages for the treatment of supratentorial brain gliomas. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the optimal dose and duration of corticosteroids. In order to detect clinically important differences in survival between different chemotherapeutic regimen regimens, no conclusions can be made about the true effect of corticosteroids on survival in patients with supratentorial brain tumors or supratentorial malignant glioma.

Treatment with the aldose reductase inhibitors leads to improved nerve conduction and vibration perception threshold in people with diabetic peripheral neuropathy. There was no evidence that the progression-free survival benefit of the drug was superior to the use of the non-invasive inhibitor. There is a need for more randomised clinical trials with long-term follow-up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from the drug.

There is limited evidence that aerobic and exercise training may be beneficial for the treatment of cancer-related fatigue, particularly when compared to usual care. There is some evidence that exercise does not improve quality of life or improve adherence to treatment. Further trials are needed to determine the effect of exercise on patient-reported outcomes.

There is some evidence that family focused grief therapy for distressed, informal carers of patients with cancer reduces the severity of debilitating depressive disorders compared with usual palliative care. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well conducted and reported long-term randomised controlled trials to determine the effectiveness of this intervention.

There is a lack of evidence from randomised controlled trials to support the routine use of switching from phenytoin to levetiracetam prophylaxis for seizure control following supratentorial glioma. The available data are too few to allow any firm conclusions to be drawn about the effectiveness and safety of switching versus levetiracetam prophylaxis in this group of patients. However, most of the included studies were small and had a high risk of bias. Further well-designed, high quality RCTs are required to determine whether switching is more effective than levetiracetam prophylaxis as a treatment for supratentorial glioma control.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of exercise for people with RA. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed and reported randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the effect of exercise on functional outcome and disease activity outcomes.

Disulfiram may be an effective pharmacotherapy for cocaine abuse among treatment-seeking opioid addicts, even in those individuals without co-morbid alcohol abuse. However, there is insufficient evidence to support or refute the routine use of this drug in the treatment of cocaine dependence.

There is no evidence to support routine use of electrostimulation for the prevention of intraoperative nausea and vomiting during spinal anaesthesia for caesarean section. There is a suggestion that electrostimulation is more effective than metoclopramide for reducing the incidence of postoperative nausea or vomiting in women undergoing elective and post-urgent caesarean section with epidural anaesthesia. However, there is some evidence that electrostimulation was superior to placebo for preventing perioperative nausea and may be associated with fewer episodes of postoperative vomiting than metoclopramide.
[Note: The 23 citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of this review once assessed.]

There is insufficient evidence to determine which method of management is the most appropriate for newborn infants with severe respiratory failure. There is a need for more randomised clinical trials with adequate trial methodology and adequate duration of follow up.

There is some evidence to support the effectiveness of psychological interventions in the treatment of patients with asthma who do not have healthcare professionals, but the quality of the evidence is poor. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials investigating the efficacy of such interventions.

In infants with acute bronchiolitis, combined therapy with beta-2 agonist epinephrine is more efficacious than oral corticosteroids in reducing the need for ED discharge and reducing the length of hospital stay, but there was no evidence of benefit in terms of important clinical outcomes.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of magnesium as a first-line treatment for moderate to severe asthma exacerbations. There is no evidence to suggest that magnesium may be an effective adjunct to beta-agonists in patients with asthma exacerbations who are discharged from the emergency department. Further well-designed RCTs are needed to assess the effect of magnesium on exacerbations such as chronic lung disease and all-cause mortality.

Results from this review suggest that the use of a typical oral contraceptive with the same dose pill is associated with a significant reduction in the risk of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, or all-cause mortality when compared to the traditional cyclic regimen of oral contraceptives. There was no evidence of a difference in the incidence of adverse events between the two pill preparations. There is a need for further well designed, adequately powered randomised controlled trials with long-term follow-up.

Manuka honey is more effective than honey as standard therapy in the healing of venous leg ulcers. There is no evidence of a difference in healing time between honey and standard therapy. There was no evidence that honey did not significantly increase the proportion of burns healed in the first two weeks of treatment when compared to standard therapy, but the difference was not statistically significant. There were no significant differences in the incidence of infection, wound colonisation, wound type, age and wound area at start of treatment with the application of honey.
It is important that honey should not be used in the treatment of people with a venous ulcer to the use of standard therapy because of the small number of available studies and the high risk of bias in the included trials.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of pentoxifylline as a treatment for intermittent claudication. There is some evidence that pentoxifylline is more effective than placebo in improving walking distance and nitric oxide levels in patients with intermittent claudication; however, the clinical significance of this is unclear. However, pentoxifylline is associated with a higher rate of adverse events than other commonly used types of drugs.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of carbamazepine as an add-on treatment for people with refractory epilepsy. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed and reported randomised trials that evaluate the effects of carbamazepine for people taking CBZ.

There is insufficient evidence to determine which multimedia or multimedia-containing interventions are the most effective treatment for childhood or chronic enuresis. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed trials of multimedia versus multimedia alone for treating children with chronic and endometrial enuresis.

Concentric is effective in reducing pain and improving functional disability in adults with knee OA but there is insufficient evidence to support its use in the short-term. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials investigating the effect of exercise on functional outcome and quality of life in people with knee pain.

There is no evidence of benefit from the use of interferon beta in the treatment of secondary progressive MS. There is insufficient evidence to show a beneficial effect of beta treatment on the outcome measures of disease progression and on the Regional Functional Status Scale. Interferon is well tolerated with no new safety concerns identified. However, the quality of the evidence was not strong enough to support the routine use of this drug in MS.
[Note: The 23 citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

There is some evidence that cognitive rehabilitation is an effective treatment for memory and cognitive functions in people with TBI. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine which type of training is the most effective for preventing cognitive functioning in the short term. Further high quality RCTs are needed to assess the effects of cognitive rehabilitation on long-term cognitive functioning outcomes.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of low-fat nutritional solutions for patients with burns. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised controlled trials to evaluate the effects of this intervention on morbidity and mortality in burns.

The use of NCPAP via an endotracheal tube to prevent extubation failure in very low birth weight infants reduces the need for weaning from mechanical ventilation and lead to failure of extubation immediately post-extubation. However, it does not seem to be associated with an increased risk of unwanted side effects or re-intubation.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of colchicine for patients with primary biliary cirrhosis. There is a need for further high-quality randomised controlled trials to determine the relative benefits and harms of colchicine.

There is no evidence to support the use of second-generation antipsychotic drugs in the treatment of negative symptoms associated with motor symptoms in people with schizophrenia. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed and reported long-term randomised controlled trials that compare the efficacy of olanzapine and risperidone with those of other commonly used atypical antipsychotics.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of urate oxidase in children with B-ALL and stage III. There is a need for high quality, adequately powered, high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this intervention.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of patient, health-care or systems interventions for the primary prevention of foot amputation in people with non-insulin-dependent diabetes. There is some evidence that these interventions are effective in reducing the prevalence of lower extremity foot amputation and the size of the lower extremity clinical disease in patients with diabetes.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of bypass during liver transplantation to reduce the risk of urinary beta2-agonist levels and improve renal function in liver transplantation. There is a need for more randomised clinical trials with larger sample sizes to assess the effects of bypass on liver transplantation outcomes.
[Note: The four citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

There is no evidence to support the routine use of growth hormone therapy for prepubertal children with CRF secondary to chronic kidney failure. There is some evidence that higher doses of human growth hormone (rhGH) are associated with increased risk of rejection and calcium and glucose metabolism compared with higher doses in the first year of treatment, but the magnitude of the effect may not be small and further research is needed.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support or refute the routine use of weaning from the incubator for preterm infants. Further well designed randomised clinical trials with long term follow-up are required.

Fluoxetine may be more effective than placebo for the treatment of moderate to severe depression, particularly when compared with other medical treatments. There was no evidence of a difference in efficacy between the two drugs. There is insufficient evidence to determine which method is the most effective and safe for treating depression.
[Note: The 23 citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of generic review once assessed.]
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of socialifers for treating people with autism. Further well-designed, adequately powered randomised controlled trials are needed.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support or refute the use of haloperidol as a treatment for people with schizophrenia. There is a need for more well designed, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCTs that compare haloperidol with other anti-rheumatic drugs (designed).

This review provides some evidence that condom use by infected couples with HIV-1 is associated with a lower risk of transmission of HIV transmission, but it is not clear whether this is worthwhile. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials to assess the effect of condom use on HIV transmission. The findings of this review should be interpreted cautiously because of the small number of studies available and the lack of adequate sample sizes of the studies.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of interferon-alpha for the treatment of acute non-A, non-B, or non-C hepatitis. There is a need for more randomised clinical trials with adequate numbers of participants, and more well designed, adequately powered, placebo-controlled trials with long-term follow up.

Reality orientation therapy combined with cholinesterase inhibitors can slow the rate of verbal and functional decline in the home for people with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease. However, there is some evidence that participation in a 6-month cognitive rehabilitation programme leads to improvements in global cognitive function as measured by the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale. There is a need for well-designed, adequately powered, high quality randomised controlled trials investigating the long-term effects of cognitive rehabilitation on cognition and global function in people with dementia.

The efficacy of topical tacrolimus 0.1%) in the treatment of oral and neovascularLP remains unclear. There is some evidence that topical tacrolimus is more effective than topical triamcinolone acetonide for treating oral monotherapies. More well-designed RCTs are needed to evaluate the long-term effectiveness of different types of topical corticosteroids in the management of neovascularLP.

Currently, there is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of home-based patient education delivered by healthcare professionals for patients with exacerbations in the short term. There is a need for more high quality randomised controlled trials that test the effectiveness of home health care delivered patient education as a means of reducing hospitalisations and, if considered, reducing admissions for exacerbations in COPD.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of occlusal interferences for the treatment of myofascial pains muscular symptom disorders in healthy children and adolescents. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed RCTs that compare the effectiveness of occlusal adjustment with other forms of treatment for myofascial pains symptom disorders including headaches.
[Note: The seven citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

There is some evidence that preoperative statin therapy reduces the incidence of postoperative AF in patients undergoing elective cardiac surgery, but the clinical significance remains unclear. There is a need for more randomised clinical trials with larger sample sizes and longer follow up to assess the effect of statin therapy on mortality and major adverse cardiac outcomes.

This review provides some evidence that breastfeeding breastfeeding mothers to be at least as effective as standard mothers to prevent HIV transmission through breastfeeding for the first six months of age for the postnatal postnatal HIV transmission of HIV. There was no evidence of a significant reduction in the rate of HIV-free survival at 18 months in the breastfeeding arm versus the control arm, but this was associated with a significant increase in the risk of HIV transmission at five months. There is no evidence to suggest that breastfeeding mothers who are breastfeeding-naive for postnatal HIV-1 are more likely to be infected with HIV than those who do not, and that it may be more effective in preventing HIV transmission via breastfeeding.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of MP as an effective treatment for affected limb recovery after stroke. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the effectiveness and safety of this intervention.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of HAI as an induction treatment for patients with resectable liver metastases from colorectal cancer. However, this conclusion is limited by the small number of included trials and small numbers of patients, methodological shortcomings, small sample sizes and lack of reporting of clinical outcomes. Further well-designed RCTs are required to determine the optimal treatment for these patients.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of a Web-based patient system to improve the quality of healthcare professionals. Large, high quality randomised controlled trials are needed to assess the effect of automated systems on patient satisfaction.

There is currently no evidence to support the routine use of endotracheal mechanical ventilation as a alternative to conventional endotracheal tube in the treatment of patients with COPD due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. There is a need for further high quality RCTs to determine the optimal duration of mechanical ventilation and the role of this technique in the management of this condition. Further well-designed, adequately powered RCTs are needed.

There is some evidence that follow-up phone calls to address the contraceptive methods of pregnant women improve adherence to oral contraceptives, however the evidence is not strong enough to support its use. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with adequate power to determine the effectiveness of this intervention.
There is insufficient evidence from randomised trials to support the use of induction versus conventional insulin therapy for the treatment of pregnant women with type 1 diabetes mellitus.

In women with FIGO stage III and IV epithelial ovarian cancer, initial therapy with a cisplatin-based chemotherapy regimen significantly improved overall survival and progression-free survival compared with the use of a carboplatin-based regimen. However, it does not seem to offer any advantage over the first three months in terms of survival or time to treatment failure.

In cancer patients with febrile neutropenia, the initial antibiotic therapy with aminoglycosides is superior to the standard combination of beta-blockers and amikacin. There is insufficient evidence to determine whether or not imipenem-cilastatin is equivalent or equivalent to current empirical treatment options for the treatment of febrile neutropenia. There was no evidence to suggest that aminoglycosides is more effective than combination therapy in terms of reducing the duration of infection, the rate of clinical cure or adverse effects when compared with the same antibiotic regimen.

This review suggests that the new atrial natriuretic peptide is beneficial in the treatment of postoperative ARF following cardiac surgery, but it is not clear which patients benefit from this treatment. However, most studies included in this review were small and of poor methodological quality. Further well-designed, high quality RCTs are needed to confirm or refute the long-term benefits and harms of this new intervention.

There is some evidence that once daily tobramycin is more effective than three-times daily tobramycin for the treatment of Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection in people with cystic fibrosis. However, there is no evidence of a difference in clinical outcomes between the two drugs. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised controlled trials that compare different doses of once daily and thrice-daily tobramycin regimens.

Minilaparotomy appears to be the most effective surgical intervention for the removal of adnexal cysts. There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of laparoscopic cystectomy as a first-line approach to the management of this condition.

There is insufficient evidence to determine whether probiotics are effective in the treatment of recurrent Clostridium difficile disease. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised controlled trials with adequate numbers of participants to determine the effect of probiotics on applicants.
[Note: The six citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the new review once assessed.]

The available data do not support the routine administration of supplementary oxygen to women undergoing elective regional anaesthesia for increasing maternal and fetal oxygenation during elective cesarean section under spinal anaesthesia.
[Note: The 23 citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of this review once assessed. Until further evidence is available, the use of oxygen supplementation for elective cesarean sections under regional anaesthesia is not justified. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised clinical trials with long-term outcomes.

The present systematic review suggests that antispastic drugs are an effective treatment for spasticity in people with multiple sclerosis, but the conclusions are tentative due to the small number of participants included in this review. There is insufficient evidence to determine which type of antispastic agent is the most appropriate for relieving spasticity in the treatment of people with MS. Large, well-designed RCTs are needed to assess the effects of these drugs on patient-reported outcomes, including well-being and intoxication symptoms.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support the routine use of prophylactic antibiotics in the treatment of open and closedcyclophosphamide fractures. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this treatment.

Epinephrine and corticosteroids are effective in reducing the length of hospital admission and the development of respiratory distress in young children with acute bronchiolitis who are treated in the pediatric emergency department. However, there is no evidence of a difference in the risk of serious adverse events when nebulised corticosteroids are compared with placebo. The clinical significance of this effect needs to be evaluated in further studies. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials that evaluate the long-term effects of corticosteroids in children with bronchiolitis.

On the basis of the findings of this review, we conclude that further randomised clinical trials are needed to confirm this. There is a need for more methodologically rigorous randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to assess the risk of stroke and recurrent ischemic stroke after a first event of cervical arteries dissection.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of formoterol dry powder in the treatment of COPD. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with adequate numbers of patients and studies with adequate follow-up periods to determine the optimal dose, timing and duration of treatment for this therapy.

There is no clear evidence that dorsal penile nerve block (EMLA) provides better pain relief for circumcision procedure time compared with no treatment. There is insufficient evidence to determine which method of anesthesia is the most effective for alleviating pain after circumcision.

There is no evidence to support the use of non-pharmacological interventions for pain relief during the first two weeks after the procedure for painful procedures in neonates. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with adequate power to evaluate the efficacy of these interventions.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support or refute the routine use of beta-blockers for the treatment of patients with chest tubes after coronary artery bypass surgery.

There is a lack of evidence from randomised controlled trials to support the use of mass topical interventions for preventing trachoma in children aged two to 35 years with clean faces. There is a need for high quality, well-designed, conducted and reported randomised trials to address the impact of such interventions on children' perception of trachoma. A single face at two or more visits may be protective for severe trachoma but the odds ratio for the prevalence of trachoma was 0.95% Cl 0.40-0.97) compared with the face only.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine whether the addition of continuous or intermittent androgen ablation to intermittent androgen deprivation improves survival in patients with advanced locally advanced prostate cancer. Further randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up are needed. Such trials should be reported according to the CONSORT guidelines (www.consort-statement.org/).
[Note: The seven citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]
There is a common side effect of toxoid for the prevention and treatment of tetanus%,atorum. However, there is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of one injection over another.

We found no significant differences between the drugs for either measure of efficacy at two or three years of follow-up or time to first seizure. There is insufficient evidence to determine which treatment is the most appropriate for treating tonic-clonic seizures, and there is some evidence to suggest that phenobarbitone is more effective than carbamazepine or carbamazepine as first choice treatment.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of diuretics as a diuretic for patients with mild to moderate heart failure. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the optimal dose and duration of diuretics for the treatment of patients with heart failure secondary to CHD.

There is insufficient evidence to determine which forms of yoga therapy is the most appropriate for treating OCD. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised controlled trials that evaluate the use of yoga techniques for patients with OCD. Future trials should be conducted before definitive conclusions can be made regarding the long-term efficacy of different forms of treatment.

There is no evidence to support the use of caffeine in the treatment of asthma. However, there is some evidence that caffeine has a small beneficial effect on quality of life and is associated with increased side effects. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed and reported long-term randomised controlled trials to assess the effects of caffeine on spirometry and exercise-induced bronchoconstriction in patients with asthma.
[Note: The three citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of NSAIDs for the development of PD. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) should not be used for the prevention of PD in clinical practice, but it is unclear whether this is associated with a higher incidence of Parkinson's disease. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed and reported randomised controlled trials investigating the effect of NSAIDs on PD.

At present, there is insufficient evidence to support the use of CAI as maintenance therapy for patients with quiescent ulcerative colitis. Further randomised clinical trials with adequate trial methodology and adequate duration of follow up are needed.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of high-dose chemotherapy with stem cell transplantation as part of the treatment of refractory disease in patients with malignant fibrous histiTootha. There is a need for further well designed, adequately powered, randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this intervention.

There is no evidence to support the use of amoxycillin in the treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy. Single-dose treatment is not inferior to conventional therapy; future study is needed to find the best single-dose regimen.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of mild hypothermia as a supplement to moderate treatment for patients with cardiac arrest. Hypothermia may be associated with improved survival when compared with no treatment. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised clinical trials with adequate numbers of participants to evaluate the effects of hypothermia for survivors of cardiac arrest with ventricular fibrillation or other vascular resistance.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support or refute the use of theophylline for the treatment of symptomatic apnea of prematurity. Further well-designed, adequately powered RCTs are required to determine whether or not to assess the effectiveness of this intervention for symptomatic apnea should be tested in clinical practice.

There is some evidence that multidisciplinary interventions to promote the use of antibiotics to patients with CAP reduce the risk of mortality and C. difficile-associated infections.
