However, the quality of the evidence was not strong enough to be influenced by publication bias. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials that examine the effects of multidisciplinary interventions on reducing the incidence of antibiotic resistance, such as antibiotics resistant to the empirical therapy, for patients with severe CAP.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of abciximab in the treatment of acute ischaemic stroke. However, there is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with adequate power to evaluate its efficacy, safety and effectiveness.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of medical record reminder for osteoporosis management after fracture. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with adequate power to evaluate the effect of this intervention.

There is currently no evidence to support the routine use of prophylactic chemotherapy for the treatment of coronary artery disease in high-risk patients. However, these results should be interpreted with caution due to the small numbers of patients and the small number of patients included in the studies. There is a need for more randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients should be treated with different types of chemotherapy.
[Note: The three citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of generic review once assessed.]

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support or refute the use of azathioprine as a treatment for generalised moderate MG. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, double-blind, placebo-controlled trials to assess the effect of azathioprine compared with other commonly used preventative drugs. In view of the modest number of patients, methodological shortcomings and poor reporting, no conclusions can be drawn regarding the effectiveness and safety of these drugs.
[Note: The three citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of generic review once assessed.]
There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine which plant is the most effective treatment for hepatitis B surface antigen in asymptomatic chronic carriers.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the routine use of amniotic membrane transplantation as a medical agent to prevent epithelial healing in people with burns. There is a need for further high quality RCTs to evaluate the role of this intervention in the treatment of burns.

There is insufficient evidence to determine which method of surgery is the most appropriate for treating patients with clavicle fractures in terms of reducing the time to union, delayed union, operative time to post-operative outcome and other complication rates. Large, well-designed randomised controlled trials are needed to assess the effectiveness of different types of surgery for treating people with clavicle and poor quality of life.

The effects of quality improvement interventions on the use of evidence-based preventive services delivery in primary care are poorly documented. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised controlled trials that explicitly addresses the effect of the intervention on the number of tests requested by primary care physicians.

There is insufficient evidence to support the effectiveness of assertiveness consultation for improving self-reported stress and assertiveness levels of stress in professional populations. There is a need for more high quality studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods that assess the effect of assertiveness training compared with other types of consultation.

This review found no significant superiority of 2 g/kg of IVIG over 5% albumin for the treatment of moderate to severe MG. The optimal dose of intravenous immunoglobulin is associated with a clinically meaningful improvement in MG clinical scores greater than 10% and a decreased MG weakness at day three. There is insufficient evidence to determine whether or not IVIG is more effective than plasma exchange or plasma exchange alone for treating chronic MG.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of fluoride toothpaste as a treatment for the development of dental caries in children and young people.

There is an urgent need for high-quality, well designed, conducted and reported long-term randomised controlled trials that evaluate the effects of topical and behavioural treatments for dental caries.

N-acetylcysteine is effective in reducing the risk of all-cause mortality in critically ill patients. However, there is no evidence for differences in any other clinical outcome between NAC and other interventions. N-acetylcysteine appears to be more effective than placebo in attenuating cardiopulmonary bypass-related acute renal failure in high-risk cardiac surgery patients.

Loxapine succinate is an effective treatment for moderate to severe schizophrenia, but is associated with a significant reduction in the incidence of adverse events. However, it is not clear whether it has an effect on quality of life or symptom control. There is a need for further well designed, adequately powered and well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow-up to assess the benefits and harms of loxapine for people with schizophrenia.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of laparoscopic nissen fundoplication as an effective treatment for gastro-oesophageal reflux disease. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from GORD treatment.

Caffeine does not appear to reduce the number of preterm infants with recurrent apnea or facilitate extubation; positive pressure positive pressure ventilation. However, there is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of prophylactic caffeine as a treatment for preterm infants. Further well-designed RCTs are needed to assess the benefits and harms associated with caffeine.
[Note: The four citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the new review once assessed.]

The laparoscopic hysterectomy seems to be as safe and effective as the laparotomy approach for the treatment of early stage endometrial cancer. The laparoscopic hysterectomy may be superior to total abdominal hysterectomy in terms of operative time, operative time without compromising, and hospital stay in women with poorly differentiated pelvic lymph node dissection, but it does not differ significantly from the conventional abdominal approach. The procedure is associated with less blood loss and higher blood loss rates; however, it was not associated with a longer hospital stay. There was no evidence of a difference in the rate of serious adverse events associated with the laparoscopic hysterectomy compared to the laparotomy procedure. Further well-designed randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up are required.

There is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of auditory stimulation as a gait-training intervention for patients with Parkinson's disease. A single RCT of six months after the end of the intervention showed no significant difference between the two types of techniques, but this conclusion can only be tentative aware that the trials were too small to detect clinically meaningful differences between the different techniques. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials to assess the effectiveness of these different techniques in the management of PD.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of a face-to-face second-line treatment for the prevention of youth who receive human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) test results and posttest counseling. Further research is needed to assess the impact of different types of telephone notification on youth's quality of life and health outcomes.

This review provides some evidence that a short-term bilateral arm training intervention reduces the movement time of the upper limb in the hemiplegic arm and improves functional gains in the upper extremity in patients with stroke. However, it is not clear which type of arm training is the most effective. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the relative effectiveness of the various types of bilateral and unilateral arm training approaches.

This review provides some evidence that adjuvant chemotherapy plus post-operative radiotherapy improves both survival and disease-free survival in patients with localised stage III or locally advanced NSCLC. However, it is associated with a higher incidence of serious adverse events and a lower incidence of clinically meaningful toxicity.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support or refute the routine use of chest physiotherapy in the treatment of acute bronchiolitis. There is a need for more high quality, well designed, well conducted and reported long-term randomised trials to evaluate the benefits and harms associated with this intervention. Such trials should be reported according to the CONSORT guidelines (www.consort-statement.org/).
[Note: The four citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

There is some evidence to support the use of a universal preventive intervention to reduce alcohol use among high-risk adolescents. There is a need for more high-quality studies investigating the long-term effectiveness of this intervention. Further research is needed to assess the effects of such interventions on the prevalence of alcohol and other problem-solving skills related to youth and their parents.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of TENS as an effective analgesic for treating pain during labour and birth. The application of TENS on specific acupuncture points could be a non-invasive adjunct for pain relief in the first stage of labour but the equivocal findings in terms of factors associated with pain relief points to the need for apparatus more specifically designed to cope with the special characteristics of the pain of labour.

This review found no evidence to support the use of botulinum toxin in the treatment ofbuffered. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed, adequately powered, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group studies that compare botulinum toxin with placebo for treatingbuffered.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the routine use of calcium and D supplementation for people with cystic fibrosis to reduce the risk of death or deterioration of bone mineral density. There is a need for more well designed, adequately powered, double-blind, placebo-controlled RCTs to assess the effects of this intervention.

There is no evidence to support the use of diazepam for the treatment of tetanus in childhood. There is a clear need for more studies with well designed, well conducted and reported long-term randomised controlled trials with adequate power to investigate the effect of diazepam on tetanus.

There is no evidence to support the routine use of pelvic brachytherapy in the treatment of women with FIGO stage-1 endometrial cancer who have lower recurrence rates and disease-free survival. There is a need for more randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine if postoperative brachytherapy is more effective than surgery alone for the prevention of treatment-related morbidity and mortality in these patients.

Covert bacteriuria does not appear to have a clear effect on the rate of infection in children under 24 months. There is no evidence to support the routine screening treatment for children with cobert bacteriuria.

We found no evidence to support the use of botulinum toxin injection for the treatment of achalasia. However, it is associated with a significant reduction in dysphagia-free state and improvement in symptom scores. There is a need for more randomised clinical trials with larger sample sizes to compare the long-term effects of injection with that of balloon dilation.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the routine use of occlusal splint techniques in the treatment of moderate to severe sleep bruxism. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this intervention. A large scale methodologically rigorous randomised controlled trial is needed to assess the efficacy and safety of different types of splints.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine whether the tubal ring is more effective than the spring-loaded clip as a first-line intervention for sterilization. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of a combination of topical and systemic treatments for non-specific low-back pain. However, there is some evidence that topical or systemic treatments are more effective than placebo for acute and chronic non-Oc pain, however, the quality of the evidence is low. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to assess the effectiveness and safety of these treatments.

PEG+E is significantly more effective than placebo, and appears to be safe and well tolerated in the treatment of functional constipation in children. There is insufficient evidence to support the use of polyethylene glycol as a treatment for children with constipation.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine whether progestogen-only contraceptives are superior to progestogen contraceptives with other injectable DMPA users for fertility free of pregnancy. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled clinical trials in this field.

There is no evidence to support the use of fibrin glue as a alternative to conventional surgical techniques for reducing the duration of post-surgical air leaks, the time to chest tube removal or the hospital stay in patients undergoing pulmonary resections. Nevertheless, there is insufficient evidence to determine which method of surgical technique is the most effective and safe for reducing postoperative air leaks after lung resections.

Inhaled steroids appears to have a beneficial effect on sputum production in people with bronchiectasis. However, there is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of ICS for the treatment of bronchiectasis. There is a need for further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to evaluate the effects of ICS on exacerbations and quality of life.

For women with moderate to severe uterine pain, NSAIDs may be more effective than placebo, and less effective than aspirin. There was no evidence of a difference in analgesic efficacy between NSAIDs and other commonly used analgesics.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of varicocelectomy as a treatment for clinical subclinical varicocele. In infertile men with a subclinical varicocele, there was no significant increase in the risk of pregnancy rate in the treatment group. There was no evidence of a difference in pregnancy rates between the two treatments, although the difference was not statistically significant.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of expectant management for women with preterm rupture of the membranes. There is no clear evidence that immediate induction of labour is associated with fewer maternal infections and fewer perinatal mortality than expectant management alone.
[Note: The four citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

There is no evidence that nebulised nebulised beta-2 agonist corticosteroids are more effective than saline placebo in decreasing the resolution of respiratory symptoms in infants with acute viral bronchiolitis, but there is insufficient evidence to conclude that it is more effective in reducing the duration of hospital admission and the need for hospital stay. There is a need for further well designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow-up to determine the optimal timing and duration of therapy for bronchiolitis.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the routine use of any one intervention for treating pain due to painful procedures in term neonates. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials that compare the effects of non-pharmacological methods, breastfeeding versus placebo, with regard to pain relief for term infants undergoing blood collection for routine screening of heel prick and blood sampling.

There is insufficient evidence to determine whether tight control of blood pressure is beneficial or harmful for the treatment of mild to moderate essential and non-ST-stage hypertension. There is a need for more randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to determine the effect of tight control on maternal and neonatal morbidity and mortality.

There is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of bracing as a brace to reduce sensitivity loss in patients with OA of the knee. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed RCTs that compare the effectiveness of bracing with other medical treatments, such as medical treatment with subtalar strapping, parkinsonism and ankle supporters, in terms of reducing sensitivity and improving knee function in adults with OA.

The available evidence suggests that alfacalcidol reduced the risk of all-cause deaths in patients with pre-dialysis secondary hyperparathyroidism when compared with placebo. Calcitriol may be more effective than vitamin D in achieving a significant decrease in serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels in the first three months after the administration of treatment. There was no evidence of a difference in the incidence of adverse events between alfacalcidol and vitamin D. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this treatment.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of electrical stimulation for the treatment of Bell's palsy. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised controlled trials with adequate numbers of participants, focusing on the possible benefits and harms of this intervention. Further well designed trials with low risk of systematic error and adequate sample sizes are needed.

There is no evidence to support the use of AVA as an effective vaccination for pre-exposure prophylaxis in healthy adults. Intramuscular administration of AVA is associated with fewer injection site adverse events. There is insufficient evidence to determine whether or not AVA is more effective than licensed vaccination in preventing injection site infections or immunogenicity pain immediately post-exposure. However, there is a need for well-designed, adequately powered, high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term outcomes that are conducted before firm recommendations for clinical practice can be made regarding its safety and efficacy.
There is currently no evidence to support the routine use of low-dose cyclosporine to treat patients with active Crohn's disease. There is a need for more randomised clinical trials.

There is no evidence to support the use of fat injection for the treatment of SUI due to ISD. There is a need for further well designed, adequately powered randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this treatment.

Subcutaneous-dose UFH is as effective and safe as low-molecular-weight UFH in the initial treatment of patients with acute venous thromboembolism. There was no evidence of a difference in the incidence of non-fatal pulmonary embolism when compared to continuous intravenous UFH. However, LMWH administered subcutaneously by an initial dose of 15-000 U/kg followed by a fixed dose of 250-100 ml/kg for six days is associated with a significant reduction in the risk of recurrent VTE and major bleeding.

There is insufficient evidence to determine whether or not IMNapism is effective in treating sickle-cell disease as an adjunctive treatment for pain attacks, or whether its use is safe or effective as an adjunct to first-line treatment in the short-term, or in preventing pain attacks in the long-term. S Laparoscopy and priapism appear to be safe and may be beneficial in treating patients with sickle-back disease.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of intramuscular or intravenous quinine for treating severe malaria in children and adolescents. Large, well-designed, randomised controlled trials are needed to confirm or refute the effectiveness and safety of the intramuscular and intravenous quinine regimen for treating children with cerebral malaria in areas where intravenous administration is delayed or is impossible.
[Note: The six citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the original review once assessed.]

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of stretching as a treatment for patellofemoral pain. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the effect of taping on pain and function.

There is some evidence that multidisciplinary community based rehabilitation is an effective treatment for people with TBI, but it is not associated with a significant reduction in the length of time spent in the short term after injury. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with longer follow up periods that explicitly address the effect of multidisciplinary rehabilitation on long-term outcome.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised trials to determine whether or not clear, or harmful, the use of Zhixue Baotaiensis for threatened miscarriage improves bleeding in women with dark area surrounding pregnancy. Further well designed RCTs are needed to assess the effects of this intervention on the short- or long-term fetus protection of women with threatened miscarriage.

There is no evidence that flosequinan has a beneficial effect on mortality when compared with placebo in patients with mild to moderate heart failure. There is a small but statistically significant increase in the risk of adverse events associated with the use of phosphodiesterase III-inhibitor drugs. However, due to the small number of trials included in this review, there is insufficient evidence to determine the long-term benefit or harm from the phosphodiesterase II inhibitor when compared to other medical treatments including diuretics, digoxin, diuretics, and β2-agonists.

There is some evidence that acupuncture is superior to placebo in the short-term treatment of acute and chronic LBP, but there is no evidence of a difference in pain relief between acupuncture and placebo. There is a need for further well designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine the effectiveness of acupuncture for these patients.

Dienogest was more effective than oral contraceptive alone for the treatment of pain associated with endometriosis, but less effective than placebo. Dienogest was associated with a significant reduction in pain relief and a significant improvement in symptom scores. There was no evidence of a difference in the incidence of side effects between the two drugs. More research is needed on the long-term effectiveness and safety of Dienogest as an effective treatment for endometriosis.

There is insufficient evidence to determine whether the routine use of dexamethasone is beneficial for treating cerebral malaria. A large scale, randomised controlled trial conducted over a greater period of time is required to determine the efficacy of this therapy for cerebral malaria survivors.

There is no evidence to support or refute the use of early immunosuppressive agents to reduce the risk of recurrence of Graves' disease in patients with successful restoration of euthyroid function. Antithyroid drugs are effective in reducing relapse within two to six months post-treatment but there is insufficient evidence to recommend its use. There is a need for further well designed, adequately powered randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from treatment.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the routine use of interferon alpha in the treatment of chronic hepatitis D. There is a need for more high quality, adequately powered, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine its efficacy.

The evidence suggests that Ty21a vaccines are more effective than placebo in preventing moderate-to-severe typhoid fever and are less effective in healthy children than for those young children. There is no evidence to support the use of a specific vaccine for preventing severe typhoid fever in high-income countries. Further well designed RCTs are needed to confirm or refute the clinical utility of the vaccines.

There is some evidence that secondary surgery significantly reduced overall survival in the short-term treatment of patients with recurrent epithelial ovarian cancer. However, secondary surgery was associated with a significant reduction in the risk of recurrence (P = 7.9 months) and a significant improvement in overall survival (R = 13.5 months) when compared to chemotherapy alone. There was no evidence of a difference in OS between the two approaches. Further research is needed to identify the long-term effects of secondary surgery on survival in these patients.

There is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of hypnosis as an effective treatment for people with persistent, progressive, or progressive motor symptoms. However, the available evidence is not robust enough to make recommendations for practice. There is a need for well designed, adequately powered, high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to assess the effectiveness of hypnosis in this patient population.

There is insufficient evidence to recommend that induction therapy with three or four drugs reduces the risk of virologic failure following maintenance therapy for HIV infection. There is a need for more high quality randomised controlled trials investigating the long-term effects of induction therapy followed by maintenance therapy with either HAART or antiretroviral therapy.

There is no evidence to support the routine use of PCT or reference platelet components for up to 28 days of transfusion in terms of increased corrected count increment, time to next transfusion, bleeding, RBC use, or transfusion-related side effects. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from this intervention.

In term and near term preterm infants, the combination of PT and SnMP significantly reduces the number of newborns required to achieve a bilirubin concentration between 48 and 96 hours and reduced the time required for the time impacting to monetary closure. No adverse effects were observed. Further trials are needed to assess the benefits and harms associated with these interventions.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of anti-chol therapies in the treatment of non-insulin-dependent diabetes. Further well-designed, adequately powered randomised controlled trials are needed.

There is some evidence to support the use of a single dose of anticholinergics in the treatment of cough associated with acute URTI and the common cold. There is insufficient evidence to draw conclusions about the effectiveness of these drugs.

The use of antibiotics for exacerbations of COPD in moderate exacerbations of mild to moderate disease shows a small but significant beneficial effect. There is no clear evidence that antibiotics may be more effective than placebo for the treatment of acute exacerbations requiring an exacerbation or in patients with chronic bronchitis. However, this finding was not statistically significant due to the small number of patients included in this review.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the effectiveness of workplace interventions for the prevention of injuries in the morning. The findings of this review suggest that workplace interventions are more effective than no intervention or other interventions for reducing the incidence of injuries, such as fatality and injury rates. There is a need for further well designed, conducted and reported long-term randomised controlled trials before and after the intervention to determine the relative effectiveness of these interventions.

There is no evidence that r-HuEPO is an effective and safe therapy for anemia in predialysis patients. However, there is some evidence that patients with pre-existing renal failure who receive EPO are more likely to experience a greater decline in renal function in terms of progression to end-stage renal failure than those who do not yet require EPO. There is a need for further large, well-designed randomised clinical trials with long-term follow-up.

Cardiotocography only compared with cardiotocography alone did not result in a significant reduction in the risk of perinatal outcome compared to cardiotocography alone. However, there was no evidence of a difference in neonatal outcome between cardiotocography and CTG. There is a suggestion that cardiotocography combined with automatic ST-waveform analysis increases the ability of obstetricians to identify fetal hypoxia and the need for fetal blood sampling without affecting the Apgar score. The use of cardiotocography plus fetal ECG may be associated with fewer caesarean section rates than cardiotocography alone, but the clinical significance of this is unclear.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of nutritional supplements for malnourished patients with CKD. Nutritional supplementation does not appear to increase calorie intake or whole body protein intake when compared to dietary advice and/or a weight loss in the short term but the magnitude of effect may not be small and it is unclear what is the most effective means for those malnourished with CKD who do not have an abnormal protein intake of 0.6 g/kg/day and 0.75 g/day for two to three weeks. Nutritional supplements can be used to increase total protein and calorie intake without causing a significant reduction in the incidence of malnutrition due to wound infection, chest infection, or antibiotic use. More high quality, well-designed studies are needed to determine the effect of supplements on weight

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the routine use of penicillin prophylaxis to reduce the incidence of infection in children with sickle cell disease. There is a lack of evidence that continued penicillin prophylaxis reduces mortality when compared to placebo, but further studies are required to determine whether it is the better choice for preventing infection in these children.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of nasal drops for people with cystic fibrosis. We found that betamethasone nasal drops showed a statistically significant reduction in polyp size in comparison to placebo. More research is required.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised trials to determine which method of endotracheal tubes is the most appropriate for reducing morbidity and mortality in neonates. There is a need for further well designed, adequately powered, randomised controlled trials to evaluate the role of endotracheal intubation with or without NT intubation for the treatment of neonates.

There is some evidence that Ginkgo biloba is an effective treatment for patients with dementia of the Alzheimer's type, but it is not clear which patients might benefit from this treatment. However, there is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of Ginkgo biloba for the treatment of patients with mild to moderate dementia. There is still a need for further well designed, adequately powered, double-blind, placebo-controlled trials that examine the efficacy of Ginkgo in treating people with Alzheimer's dementia.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of prophylactic prenatal prevention programmes for preventing preterm birth in high-risk women. Further high quality randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up are required.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to support or refute the routine use of exercise therapy for people with the chronic fatigue syndrome. There is a need for well designed, conducted and reported randomised clinical trials with long-term follow up to evaluate the benefits and harms of this intervention.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of low molecular weight heparin as an effective treatment to prevent graft patency in patients with peripheral arterial bypass surgery. Large, high quality, randomised controlled trials with long-term follow up are needed to determine the optimal management of these patients.

Individual dependence is an effective treatment for short-term smoking cessation but the magnitude of the benefit is small and may not be clinically meaningful. However, there is insufficient evidence to recommend nicotine replacement as an adjunct to low-intensity primary care or to support self-help support for the maintenance of the non-smoking activity of smokers.

There is no evidence to support the routine use of omega 3/6 fatty acids as a supplement to reducing the symptoms of ADHD in children and adolescents. There is a need for further well designed, conducted and reported long-term randomised controlled trials that evaluate the effects of these treatments on clinically important outcomes.

We found no evidence to support the routine use of oral erythromycin for the treatment of enteral feeding in preterm infants with feeding intolerance. There is some evidence that this intervention does not significantly reduce the chance of adverse events associated with enteral feeds in very low birth weight infants. Erythromycin is associated with fewer episodes of gastric enterocolitis and may be associated with shorter full enteral feeding compared with placebo, but the clinical significance of this is unclear.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of vitamin D supplementation in people with X-linked hypophosphatemia. Further well-designed, adequately powered RCTs are required to assess the effect of this intervention on short-term growth hormone secretion in children and adolescents.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of vitamin A as an adjunct to treat childhood pneumonia in children under two years of age. There is no evidence to suggest that vitamin A is an effective treatment for childhood pneumonia, but the evidence is not strong enough to recommend its use. Further well-designed, adequately powered randomised controlled trials are needed to assess the benefits and harms associated with vitamin A.

The available evidence suggests that topical interferon is an effective treatment for superficial and chronic nodular cell carcinoma, but it is not clear whether this is associated with a higher incidence of adverse events. There is insufficient evidence to determine which treatment is the most appropriate for these tumours. There was no evidence to suggest that surgery is superior to the use of either topical or systemic cryotherapy in the treatment of these tumours, or that it is more effective in the short-term for higher recurrence than surgery in the long-term.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of penicillin with oral amoxicillin as a treatment for WHO-defined severe pneumonia in children aged 3 to 59 months or in adults aged two years. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed and reported RCTs that compare penicillin with parenteral or oral amoxicillin for the treatment of pneumonia in people aged 5 years or more.
